questions.text: Which type of joint is the talocalcaneonavicular joint?
questions.solution:
Talocalcaneonavicular joint is a ball and socket type of synovial joint. 

 It resembles a ball and socket joint in several ways. The head of talus is inserted into a socket that is partially formed by the navicular bone and partially by the calcaneum. The medial limb of the bifurcate ligament laterally and the spring ligament medially both contribute to the formation of the socket.

Other options: -

  • Ellipsoid joint - metacarpophalangeal joint, metatarsophalangeal joint.
  • Hinge joint- Elbow, ankle joint.
  • Saddle joint- sternoclavicular joint, calcaneocuboid joint.
 

Reference : BD CHAURASIA , VOL-2 ,7th Edition ,Pg-152

choices.text: Present medial to the white ramus communicans

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about grey communicans?
questions.solution:
The sympathetic ganglia present on either side of the vertebral column are connected to spinal nerves by white and grey rami communicans. The cell bodies of the preganglionic sympathetic nervous system neurons are present in lateral horn of spinal cord. They leave the cord via ventral root to enter spinal nerves. From spinal nerves, they enter the sympathetic ganglia via white rami communicans and synapse with cell bodies of postganglionic sympathetic neurons. The axons of the postganglionic sympathetic neurons re-enter the spinal nerves via grey rami communicans. 

To summarize- 

1. White rami communicans- Preganglionic sympathetic fibers, myelinated ( type B ) and release acetylcholine

2. Grey rami communicans- Postganglionic sympathetic fibers, unmyelinated ( type C ) and release norepinephrine. 

Trick- All neurons which exit the central nervous system- brain and spinal cord such as cranial nerves, preganglionic parasympathetic and sympathetic fibers release acetylcholine. 

Reference- BD CHAURASIA ,VOL-3,7th Edition Pg-160

questions.text: Which muscle type is shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Multipennate The image shows the pectoralis major muscle. The pectoralis major muscle is classified as multipennate, not unipennate. Multipennate muscles have multiple tendons with muscle fibers that branch out diagonally in a feather-like pattern from the central tendon. The pectoralis major has several tendons with muscle fibers extending in different directions, giving it a multipennate arrangement.
 

Other options: -

Option 1: Cruciate: Muscle fibres are arranged in X shape. Ex:- Sternocleidomastoid

Option 3: Parallel: Muscle fibres in these muscle run parallel to the length of muscle. Ex:- Biceps brachi

Option 4: Unipennate: Muscle fibres are arranged on one side of tendon. Ex:- Extensor digitorum

Reference : Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice,41st Edition - page no.112

questions.text: Which of the following are transversely oriented canals that offer a radial blood flow path?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2:  Volkmann's canal
 

  • Volkmann's canals, also known as perforating canals, are small channels in bone tissue.
  • They run transversely (horizontally) to the long axis of the bone.
  • Volkmann's canals connect the Haversian canals within the Haversian systems (osteons) of compact bone.
  • Their primary function is to provide a radial blood flow path from the periosteum (outer surface) to the endosteum (inner surface) of the bone.
  • This radial arrangement ensures efficient vascular supply and communication between different parts of the bone.
  • It allows blood vessels, nerves, and connective tissue to traverse through the bone for nourishment and support.

Reference : Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice,41st Edition - page no.89

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the characteristics of lamellar bone?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Haversian system
 

  • Lamellar bone is a type of bone tissue that is characterized by the presence of Haversian systems. Haversian systems are cylindrical structures that are made up of concentric layers of lamellae, which are thin sheets of bone tissue.
  • The Haversian system is a fundamental unit of compact bone that provides strength and support to the bone.
  • The lamellae are arranged in a regular pattern, and they are surrounded by a central canal that contains blood vessels and nerves.
  • Lamellar bone is the most common type of bone tissue in the adult skeleton.
  • It is found in the outer layer of cortical bone, as well as in the trabecular bone that makes up the inner part of some bones.

Reference : Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice,41st Edition - page no.88

questions.text: To which variety does the atlantoaxial joint belong?

questions.text: Which of the following is an exception to the facts about intervertebral disc -
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Annulus Fibrosus  is derived from Notochord 
 
  • The annulus fibrosus, which is the outer fibrous ring of the intervertebral disc, is not derived from the notochord. Instead, it is made up of concentric rings of fibrocartilage.
  •  It is the outer layer of the intervertebral disc and it is responsible for providing the disc with its strength and stability.
  • It is the outer layer of the intervertebral disc and it is responsible for providing the disc with its strength and stability.
  • The notochord is an embryonic structure that plays a crucial role in the early development of the vertebral column, but it does not directly contribute to the formation of the annulus fibrosus. Nucleus pulposus is the remnant of notochord and acts as a shock absorber.

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 87,121,123

questions.text: Which of the following structures has additional synovial, intracapsular tissue?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1:  Long Biceps Tendon
 
  • The long biceps tendon is located in the shoulder joint, specifically in the intertubercular groove of the humerus.
  • It is part of the biceps brachii muscle, which has two tendons - the long head and the short head. The long head of the biceps tendon travels within the shoulder joint and has a synovial sheath that allows it to move smoothly and reduce friction during joint movement.
  • Inside the shoulder joint, the long biceps tendon has additional synovial, intracapsular tissue because of its sheath, which is not present in the other structures listed.
 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 917

questions.text: Label the given histopathological cross section of epiphyseal cartilage which contains rapidly dividing chondrocytes
questions.solution:
B Rapidly Proliferating layer

Epiphyseal cartilage is divided into five zones :
  • ‚óè The resting zone consists of hyaline cartilage without morphological changes in the cells.
  • Proliferative zone consists of chondrocytes that divide rapidly and form columns of stacked cells parallel to the long axis of the bone.
  • The hypertrophic cartilage zone contains large chondrocytes whose cytoplasm has accumulated glycogen. -calcified cartilage zone is formed by the death of Chondrocytes and the thin septa of cartilage matrix become calcified by the deposit of hydroxyapatite.
  • The ossification zone contains endochondral bone tissue
Reference: Amizuka N, Hasegawa T, Oda K, Luiz de Freitas PH, Hoshi K, Li M, Ozawa H. Histology of epiphyseal cartilage calcification and endochondral ossification. Front Biosci (Elite Ed). 2012 Jan 1;4(6):2085-100. doi: 10.2741/e526. PMID: 22202021.

questions.text: What type of joint is seen at the labelled structure
questions.solution:
The pubic symphysis is a classic example of a secondary cartilaginous joint (also called a symphysis). Here's why:

  • It is a midline joint between the two pubic bones.

  • The bones are united by a fibrocartilaginous disc.

  • Articular surfaces are covered by hyaline cartilage, but the intervening disc is fibrocartilage.

  • It allows limited movement, particularly important during childbirth (hormonal influence causes slight softening and increased mobility).

    Types of Joints Table

     

    Type Sub-type Tissue Between Bones Mobility Examples
    Fibrous joints Sutures Dense fibrous connective tissue Immovable (synarthrosis) Skull sutures (in children)
    Syndesmosis Interosseous ligament/membrane Slightly movable Inferior tibiofibular joint
    Gomphosis Periodontal ligament Immovable Tooth in alveolar socket
    Cartilaginous joints Primary (Synchondrosis) Hyaline cartilage Immovable Epiphyseal plate, 1st costochondral joint
    Secondary (Symphysis) Fibrocartilage + hyaline ends Slightly movable Pubic symphysis, intervertebral discs
    Synovial joints Various (6 types) Synovial cavity + articular cartilage Freely movable (diarthrosis) Knee, shoulder, hip, elbow, etc.

Reference:Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice 41st edition page no 96

questions.text: The vertical plane that divides the body into anterior and posterior parts is known as
questions.solution:
• Coronal plane (also called frontal plane) divides the body into anterior (front) and posterior (back) sections.

  • Median plane (or midsagittal plane) divides the body into equal left and right halves.

  • Axial plane is another term for the transverse plane, which divides the body into superior (upper) and inferior (lower) parts.

  • Transverse plane refers to a horizontal cut through the body.

So, a vertical plane dividing front and back is the coronal plane.




Reference:Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice 41st edition page no 16

questions.text: What are the following structures in the given image of axilla?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: 1-Medial cord of brachial plexus, 2-long thoracic nerve, 3-subscapularis

Structure 1: Medial cord of brachial plexus
  • It is a part of the brachial plexus, a network of nerves that supplies the upper limb.
  • The medial cord gives rise to multiple nerves responsible for innervating various muscles and structures in the upper limb.

Structure 2: Long thoracic nerve
  • It originates from the roots of the brachial plexus.
  • The long thoracic nerve supplies the serratus anterior muscle.
  • It plays a crucial role in stabilizing the scapula during movements of the upper limb.

Structure 3: Subscapularis
  • The subscapularis is one of the four muscles that form the rotator cuff in the shoulder region.
  • It is located on the anterior surface of the scapula (shoulder blade) and aids in the internal rotation of the arm.
 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42nd Page no 927.

questions.text: Which among the following muscles does not insert at the greater tubercle of humerus?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, subscapularis does not insert to the greater tubercle of humerus. 

It arises from the subscapularis fossa, fills it, and attaches on the humerus at its lesser tubercle.

For its isolated insertion at lesser tubercle as compared to supraspinatus, infraspinatus and teres minor which insert together at the greater tubercle, it is often called as the forgotten muscle of rotator cuff.

questions.text: For which of the following muscles is a card test performed?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Palmar interossei
 
  • A card test is performed for the palmar interossei muscles. This test assesses the function of these muscles, which are responsible for adducting the fingers towards the middle finger.
  • To perform the card test, a small card or piece of paper is placed between the patient's fingers, and they are asked to hold it tightly. If the card can be pulled out easily, it indicates weakness in the palmar interossei muscles.

Other tests:
  • Egawa test- for Dorsal interossei
  • Froment's sign- for Adductor pollicis
 

Reference: Essential Orthopaedics Maheshwari, 7th Edition, Page no 67,68.

questions.text: A patient who was unable to move his fourth and fifth fingers, hold a pen, or hold a piece of paper between his fingers was presented. Which of the sites listed below is most likely to have caused the nerve injury
questions.solution:
Correct answer, Option 4: D, which shows the medial epicondyle of humerus behind which the ulnar nerve passes. Ulnar nerve supplies the medial half of Flexor Digitorum Profundus which causes flexion of fourth and fifth fingers and palmar interossei which causes adduction of fingers. Thus in ulnar nerve injury the patient as mentioned in the question, fails to move his 4th and 5th fingers and card test is positive( Inability to hold paper/card in between fingers).



Reference-: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition Page no 984,984.e1

  • Ulna is not engaged in the development of the wrist because the articular disc excludes it from the wrist joint.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old patient came to see you with flexion at the proximal interphalangeal joint and hyperextension of the 4th and 5th metacarpophalangeal joints.
The likely nerve injured is:
questions.solution:
An ulnar nerve injury that causes partial or complete denervation of the ulnar (medial) two lumbricals of the hand may be followed by an ulnar claw.
Due to the fact that the ulnar nerve supplies the third and fourth lumbrical, which flex the MCP joints, its denervation enables these joints to extend as a result of the long finger extensors' now-unopposed action (namely the extensor digitorum and the extensor digiti minimi). By inserting into the extensor hood,the lumbrical and interossei also extend the IP (interphalangeal) joints of the fingers; their paralysis leads to weakened extension. Combined with hyperextension at the MCP provides the hand its claw-like shape.






Reference-: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition Page no 984,984.e1

questions.text: Which nerve is involved in pronator teres syndrome?
questions.solution:
The median nerve at the elbow is compressed in pronator teres syndrome.
The muscles innervated including the flexor pollicis longus (FPL), the flexor digitorum profundus of the index finger (FDP IF), and the pronator quadratus, can become weak as a result of compression of the median nerve in the area of the elbow.





Reference- https://www.physio-pedia.com/Pronator_Teres_Syndrome_Test

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman who has Ca Breast underwent a mastectomy. The ability to extend, adduct, and internally rotate the arm is impaired after mastectomy.
Which muscle's nerve supply has suffered damage?
questions.solution:
• Thoracodorsal Nerve- supplies Latissimus dorsi- Extension, Adduction, Internal rotation of arm
  • Long thoracic Nerve- supplies Serratus Anterior- Overhead(>90) abduction of arm
  • Intercostobrachial Nerve- Sensory supply to skin of upper half of arm.
Above nerves are prone to damage during mastectomy, and therefore patient will not be able to perform these movements. 
Remember- The most common nerve injured during modified radical mastectomy is intercostobrachial nerve ( T2)



Reference-: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition Page no 832

questions.text: Which nerve may be involved in the malformation seen below?
questions.solution:
This image is showing partial Claw hand sign which is seen in Ulnar nerve damage.

Ulnar nerve supplies
1. 3rd and 4th Lumbricals 
2. Palmar and Dorsal interossei

3/4th lumbrical are required for PIP and DIP extension at 4th/5th digits, and 4th/5th digit flexion at MCP joint.
Hence, ulnar nerve damage will lead to flexion at 4th/5th digit PIP and DIP joints, and extension at  4th/ 5th digit MCP joints leading to partial ulnar claw hand.




Note: The image given is not of Benediction(Pope) sign. In Benedict sign (which occurs due to median nerve damage) - there is loss of 1st and 2nd lumbricals (which helps in 2/3rd digits MCP Flexion) - leading to extension at index/middle finger MCP joint. But since 3/4th lumbrical are spared - there is flexion at 4/5th digit MCP joint. 
The main difference is at 4/5th digit MCP joint - In ulnar claw hand - 4/5th digit MCP joint would be extended; while 4th/5th digit MCP in benedict sign(median nerve injury) would be flexed. 




Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition Page no 984,984.e1

questions.text: What does the phrase "dynamic stabiliser of the shoulder joint" refer to?
questions.solution:
'Dynamic stabilizer of shoulder joint’ is used for rotator cuff or musculotendinous cuff.

The tendons of the subscapularis, supraspinatus, infraspinatus, and teres minor muscles that are united to the underlying capsule of the shoulder joint are referred to as the rotator cuff. The cuff is crucial in maintaining the stability of the shoulder joint.



Reference-: Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition Page no 813,785.e1

questions.text: Which nerve root supplies the thumb and index finger dermatomes ?
questions.solution:
The thumb and index finger dermatomes are supplied by the C6 and C7 nerve roots , respectively. The dermatomes are the areas of skin innervated by the various spinal nerve roots. The C6 nerve root innervates the thumb, while the C7 nerve root innervates the index finger. The C5, C6, C7, and C8 nerve roots supply the muscles of the hand and wrist, and they are responsible for sensation in the corresponding dermatomes.




 

Reference:Campbell's Operative Orthopaedics, 13th edition Page no 1445

questions.text: Understanding of the mechanics of the muscles surrounding the shoulder joint also referred to as the "rotator cuff muscles," have grown. exponentially. One of the rotator cuff muscles, often regarded as the "lost rotator cuff muscles," has, however, had its function neglected or given less significance. Which of the four muscles most accurately fits the bill for this description?
questions.solution:
The Subscapularis, one of the major and most powerful muscles of the rotator cuff, is often overlooked in the clinical literature, even though it is essential to glenohumeral stability and dynamics. It has been deemed that the subscapularis tendon is the "forgotten tendon" due to its separate insertion at lesser tubercle of humerus as compared to rest of the 3 muscles which get inserted at greater tubercle. 

The rotator cuff muscles are :
1. Subscapularis
2. Supraspinatus
3. Infraspinatus
4. Teres Minor ( and not major )



Reference-: Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition Page no 813,785.e1

questions.text: Identify the function of the muscle at Metacarpophalangeal joint shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Flexion The muscles shown in the image are the lumbricals muscles. The lumbricals are a group of four small muscles located in the hand. They originate from the tendons of the flexor digitorum profundus and insert onto the extensor expansion of the fingers. The primary function of the lumbricals is to flex the metacarpophalangeal joints and extend the interphalangeal joints of the fingers. This action allows for finger flexion and helps with gripping and holding objects.




Reference: Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition Page no 883,885

questions.text: All of the following movements occur during abduction of shoulder except
questions.solution:
Abduction of shoulder involves the elevation of the humerus, axial rotation of the clavicle, and acromioclavicular joint movement. However, it does not involve medial rotation of the scapula. Medial rotation of the scapula is a movement that rotates the scapula inwards. This movement is involved in adduction of the shoulder, not abduction.




Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK537148/

questions.text: Select the option that is not a composite muscle.
questions.solution:
‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚ÄãComposite muscles or hybrid muscles are those which have more than one set of fibers but perform the same function AND supplied by different sets of nerves for different fibers . EXAMPLE: FDP- median and ulnar, pectinus - femoral and obturator, biceps femoris - tibial of sciatic, common peroneal, FPB- median and ulnar and many more.

questions.text: Which group of muscles given below are affected in claw hand?
questions.solution:
The claw hand presented here is a condition in which the intrinsic muscles of the hand are affected. These muscles are primarily supplied by the ulnar nerve, which is also known as the nerve of fine movements. The median nerve supplies some of the intrinsic muscles through its recurrent branch (1st and 2nd lumbricals, and thenar group of muscles, except for the deep head of the flexor pollicis brevis). The anterior interosseous nerve, which is a branch of the median nerve, does not supply any of the intrinsic muscles of the hand. Similarly, the radial nerve and its branch, the posterior interosseous nerve, do not supply any of the intrinsic muscles of the hand.




Reference-: Ebnezar's Textbook of Orthopedics 5th Edition Page no 62

questions.text: The deformity depicted in the picture below occurs for which nerve injury?
questions.solution:
This image is showing partial Claw hand sign which is seen in Ulnar nerve damage.

Ulnar nerve supplies
1. 3rd and 4th Lumbricals 
2. Palmar and Dorsal interossei

3/4th lumbrical are required for PIP and DIP extension at 4th/5th digits, and 4th/5th digit flexion at MCP joint.
Hence, ulnar nerve damage will lead to flexion at 4th/5th digit PIP and DIP joints, and extension at  4th/ 5th digit MCP joints leading to partial ulnar claw hand.




Note: The image given is not of Benediction(Pope) sign. In Benedict sign (which occurs due to median nerve damage) - there is loss of 1st and 2nd lumbricals (which helps in 2/3rd digits MCP Flexion) - leading to extension at index/middle finger MCP joint. But since 3/4th lumbrical are spared - there is flexion at 4/5th digit MCP joint. 
The main difference is at 4/5th digit MCP joint - In ulnar claw hand - 4/5th digit MCP joint would be extended; while 4th/5th digit MCP in benedict sign(median nerve injury) would be flexed. 





Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition Page no 984,984.e1

questions.text: The axillary artery is split into three sections by:
questions.solution:
Correct Option 2:Pectoralis Minor

  • The three sections are:
1- First part: Superior to the pectoralis minor muscle.
2-Second part: Below the pectoralis minor muscle, but still anterior to the subscapularis muscle.
3-Third part: Below the subscapularis muscle, and posterior to the teres major muscle.
 
  • The pectoralis minor muscle is a small triangular muscle that lies in the anterior axilla.
  •  It originates from the third, fourth, and fifth ribs, and inserts onto the coracoid process of the scapula.
  • The pectoralis minor muscle helps to stabilize the shoulder joint and to move the arm forward.

questions.text: The number of intrinsic hand muscles that the ulnar nerve supplies is:
questions.solution:
Four muscle groups comprise the intrinsic hand. These are the thenar, hypothenar, interossei and the lumbrical muscles. Amongst these ulnar nerve supplies

A. Hypothenar Muscles (3+1* muscles)
1. Abductor digiti minimi (ADM)
2. Flexor digiti minimi brevis (FDMB)
3. Opponens digiti minimi (ODM)

Also supplies - Palmaris brevis (superficial to Hypothenar muscles)

B. Interossei (8 muscles)
1.Dorsal interossei (4 muscles)
2. Palmar interossei (4muscles)

C. Lumbricals (2 muscles)
3rd and 4th Lumbrical is supplied by Ulnar nerve

D. Thenar muscles (1 muscle)
Adductor pollicis 

Adding up all these intrinsic hand muscles supplied by the ulnar nerve, we get a total of 4+8+2+1+1+ =15 muscles.

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition Page no 984

questions.text:
At which of the following levels does an Inverted Supinator Jerk indicate a lesion?
1. C5, C6
2. C6, C7
3. L5, S1
4. L4, S1
questions.solution:
• The Inverted Supinator Jerk (also known as the Supinator or Brachioradialis Reflex) is a neurological test used to evaluate the function of the musculocutaneous nerve (C5, C6).
  • During the test, the examiner taps or strikes the distal forearm just proximal to the wrist while the patient's elbow is slightly flexed and the forearm is resting on the examiner's hand.
  • The normal response is flexion of the forearm at the elbow, which is caused by contraction of the biceps brachii muscle.



Trick to memorize reflexes nerve roots:- 
Biceps and brachioradialis reflex- C5,6 ( pick up the stick)
Triceps reflex- C6,7 ( Lay them straight)
Achilles reflex- S1,2 ( Buckle my shoe)
Patellar reflex- L2-4 ( Kick the door)
Cremasteric reflex- L1,2 ( Testicles move)

Did you get the rhythm  of the last digit with the action of reflex?

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with loss of sensation over the lateral three and a half digits on the volar side. He also had associated pain. The patient would sometimes wake up from sleep due to pain and hanging the hand over the edge of the bed would help relieve the pain. What is the most probable site of injury and which test can be performed to confirm the same?
questions.solution:
Answer is option (1) Carpal Tunnel and Durkan Compression Test

This patient reports loss of sensation/ paresthesia over the lateral three and a half digits on the volar side. This corresponds to the sensory distribution of the median nerve.
  • The median nerve may be compressed at the level of the carpal tunnel. Carpal Tunnel Syndrome arises due to anatomic compression or inflammation. 
  • Clinical examination of the Median Nerve involves:
  1. Assessment of sensory loss: The palmar cutaneous branch of the median nerve passes above the carpal tunnel and supplies the skin of the thenar eminence. Thus, this area is typically spared, and sensory loss over the thenar eminence would indicate a more proximal lesion.
  2. Assessment of motor function: The median nerve supplies five muscles including three muscles of the thenar eminence - flexor pollicis brevis (FPB), opponens pollicis (OP) and abductor pollicis brevis (APB), along with the first and second lumbricals.  In severe or advanced CTS, muscles of the thenar eminence may be affected leading to weakness of thumb abduction (APB)  and thumb opposition (OP.) 
  3. Provocative maneuvers/ tests:
  • Phalen test:  The patient brings the dorsal surfaces of the hands against each other to provide hyperflexion of the wrist. If pain/ paresthesia in the distribution of the median nerve is elicited the test is positive.
 
 
  • Tinel test: Percussion performed over the course of the median nerve just proximal to the carpal tunnel elicits pain/ paresthesias in the distribution of the median nerve.
 
 
  • Durkan test or manual carpal compression: Pressure is applied over the transverse carpal ligament for 30 seconds. Pain/ paresthesia indicates a positive result.
 
 
  • Hand elevation test: The patient raises the hands above the head for one minute. If the symptoms are reproduced, the test is positive.
Reference: Apley & Solomon's Concise System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th Edition, Page No 297, 298, 303.

questions.text: A patient presented with the extension of MCP joint and flexion of IP joints. Which muscle is affected?
questions.solution:
• The described posture — extension at the MCP joints and flexion at the IP joints — is known as the “claw hand” posture.

  • This occurs due to paralysis of the interossei and lumbrical muscles, which normally:

    • Flex the MCP joints

    • Extend the IP joints

  • When these muscles are paralyzed, the extrinsic extensors (extensor digitorum) act unopposed at the MCP joint, and the flexors of the PIP and DIP joints act unopposed at the IP joints, producing the clawed appearance.

Other options:

  • Abductor pollicis: Moves the thumb away from the palm; does not cause this posture.

  • Extensor digitorum: Extends fingers at MCP and IP joints; unopposed action contributes to clawing but is not the primary affected muscle.

  • Abductor pollicis brevis: Abducts the thumb; unrelated to this deformity.

Mnemonic:

questions.text: What is the type of joint marked in the given image?
questions.solution:
The joint indicated in the given image is the first carpometacarpal joint.

It is classified as a saddle type of synovial joint.

In a saddle joint, the articular surfaces are reciprocally concavo-convex. In contrast, all other carpometacarpal joints are plane type joints.


Key points:

  • Saddle joint characteristics:

    • Both articulating surfaces are concave in one direction and convex in the other, resembling a saddle.

    • Allows flexion, extension, abduction, adduction, and circumduction, plus opposition of the thumb.

  • This joint is crucial for precision grip and thumb mobility.

  • Condylar joint: Found in the MCP joints (2nd–5th fingers), allows similar movements but less rotational freedom.

Other joint types for context:

  • Ellipsoid: Wrist joint (radiocarpal)

  • Plane: Intercarpal joints

questions.text: Identify the tendon marked in the image?
questions.solution:
The tendon marked in the image appears to be Palmaris Longus (Option 3).

The Palmaris Longus tendon is a thin, superficial tendon that becomes prominent when the wrist is flexed, especially if the thumb and little finger are opposed.
It runs centrally in the forearm and inserts into the palmar aponeurosis.
This tendon is absent in about 10-15% of the population.

The Flexor Carpi Radialis is located more laterally (toward the thumb), and Flexor Carpi Ulnaris is positioned more medially (toward the little finger).

The Median nerve is not typically visible in this manner, as it runs deeper in the forearm.

questions.text: Identify the anatomical structure marked in the given image
questions.solution:
Boundaries:

  • Lateral (radial) border:

    • Abductor pollicis longus (APL) and extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) tendons

  • Medial (ulnar) border:

    • Extensor pollicis longus (EPL) tendon

  • Proximal border:

    • Styloid process of the radius

  • Floor:

    • Scaphoid and trapezium bones

  • Contents:

    • Radial artery (runs through the snuff box)

    • Superficial branch of the radial nerve

    • Cephalic vein (lateral aspect)

Clinical significance:

  • The radial artery pulse can be palpated here.

  • Scaphoid fractures may present with tenderness in the snuff box.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male came in with an inability to flex the distal interphalangeal joints of his 4th and 5th fingers. He was also unable to hold a piece of paper between his fingers. What is the most likely site of injury?
questions.solution:
• The clinical scenario, characterized by a positive card test and the inability to flex the distal interphalangeal joints of the 4th and 5th digits, points towards an ulnar nerve injury. The most likely site of injury would be the medial epicondyle (site C).
 
  • An injury at the medial epicondyle affects the ulnar nerve, resulting in paralysis of the flexor carpi ulnaris (causing loss of ulnar deviation) and the medial half of the flexor digitorum profundus (causing loss of flexion at the distal interphalangeal joints).
  • This also leads to paralysis and atrophy of the hypothenar muscles, along with sensory loss. However, because the flexor digitorum superficialis (innervated by the median nerve) and the extensor digitorum (innervated by the radial nerve) remain functional, complete paralysis of the 3rd and 4th digits does not occur.
  • The positive card test results from weakness in the palmar interossei, leading to impaired adduction.


Branches and innervation of the ulnar nerve:
- The superficial branch supplies the palmaris brevis and the skin over the palmar surface of the medial one and a half fingers.
- The deep branch travels along the deep palmar arch and innervates all the intrinsic hand muscles, except the first two lumbricals and the thenar muscles.


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st edition, Page no 784, 785, 859, 860 .

questions.text: Which of the following nerve can be injured, when a fracture is sustained at the area marked with the red arrow in the given image?
questions.solution:
In the provided image, the arrow indicates the medial epicondyle. A fracture at this site can result in damage to the ulnar nerve.

The nerves associated with the humerus include:

The axillary nerve, located at the surgical neck.
The ulnar nerve, positioned at the medial epicondyle.
The radial nerve, found at the spiral groove of the humeral shaft.
Ulnar nerve branches and their functions:

The superficial branch supplies the palmaris brevis and the skin on the palmar surface of the medial 1½ fingers.
The deep branch traverses within the concavity of the deep palmar arch and innervates all the intrinsic muscles of the hand, except for the first two lumbricals and the thenar muscles.

questions.text: A patient is referred to a higher center with the diagnosis of fracture. On examination, the forearm pulses were not palpable. An upper arm X-ray was done which is given below. Which artery is most likely to be injured in this condition?
questions.solution:
In the presented clinical scenario, the history and radiographic findings indicate a closed fracture of the humeral shaft. In such cases, the brachial artery is the artery most frequently injured.

Additionally, the radial nerve is often compromised in this condition, resulting in wrist drop and finger drop due to the inability to dorsiflex the wrist and fingers. Patients may experience numbness on the dorsoradial aspect of the hand and the dorsal surface of the radial three and a half digits.



Management of humeral shaft fractures includes:

Conservative management: This involves reducing the fracture and applying a hanging cast or U-slab for 2-3 weeks, followed by functional bracing.
Surgical fixation: This is warranted in the following cases:
Open fractures
Pathological fractures
Unstable humeral and forearm fractures (floating elbow)
Radial nerve palsy

questions.text: A 60 year old man following a fall from a height and sustaining injury to the back of his neck is unable to shrug his shoulders. Which of the following structures is more likely to be injured?
questions.solution: Shrugging of shoulders is carried out by the trapezius which is supplied by the spinal accessory nerve. Spinal accessory is a content of the posterior triangle of the neck. It also supplies the sternocleidomastoid before entering the triangle hence injury to the nerve at the triangle will spare the sternocleidomastoid. Ref- Grays Anatomy 41st edition Page 781,831

questions.text: What is the condition shown in this picture?
questions.solution:
When the tendon in the proximal biceps ruptures, the Popeye sign appears. The long and short heads of the biceps are included in the proximal biceps tendon.

Popeye sign: named after cartoon character Popeye, whose signature physique prominently features this bulge. The unregulated contracting of the muscular fibers causes the belly of the muscle to prominently protrude when the elbow is flexed.

questions.text: A schoolboy presented with the following finding. He has a history of trauma to his upper arm in the past. Which nerve is most likely to be injured in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given image is suggestive of wrist drop: paralysis of the wrist and finger dorsiflexors, caused due to damage to the radial nerve.

Symptoms of Radial nerve injury:
wrist drop (due to paralysis of extensors of wrist and fingers)
Numbness over the dorsal side of the radial 3 1/2 digits
Numbness over the anatomical snuff box
loss of sensation in dorsal aspect of arm and forearm (in high radial nerve injury)

Saturday night palsy: compression of the radial nerve in the axilla, which is characterized by weakness in the wrist and hand and paralysis of the triceps.
Because of the nerve's intimate anatomical link to the bone, humeral shaft fractures are among the most prevalent causes of radial nerve injury (given in the above question as history of trauma to his upper arm in the past).

Other options



Reference
1.Apley's System Of Orthopaedics And Fractures - 10th Edition , Pg 770
2.Rockwood and Green's Fractures in Adults 8th edition - Pg "1287

questions.text: A patient with leprosy presented with the deformity as shown below. Which nerve injury causes the given condition ?
questions.solution:
The image of claw hand is typically associated with ulnar nerve palsy.

  • In ulnar nerve injury, there is:

    • Paralysis of medial two lumbricals (which normally flex the MCP and extend the IP joints of ring and little fingers)

    • Unopposed action of the long extensors at the MCP and long flexors at the IP joints

    • Resulting in hyperextension at MCP and flexion at PIP and DIP joints of the 4th and 5th fingers — the classic "claw hand" deformity

      Other options:

  • Posterior interosseous nerve (PIN): A branch of the radial nerve; causes wrist and finger extension weakness but not claw hand.

  • Median nerve: Injury causes “ape thumb” or “hand of benediction” (not true claw).

  • Radial nerve: Injury leads to wrist drop, not claw hand.

     In leprosy:

  • The ulnar nerve is the most commonly affected peripheral nerve.

  • Chronic neuropathy causes muscle wasting and clawing of the 4th and 5th fingers.

questions.text: Which joints' axes move parallel to one another as the foot pronates?

These two axes are comparatively divergent when the subtalar joint is in a neutral position.
However, these two axes become parallel as the subtalar joint pronates, i.e. during the unlocking of the foot.

questions.text: Which of these is accurate regarding the menisci of knee joint:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3:Medial meniscus covers the most of the articular surface of proximal tibia

 

Each knee joint contains two menisci, which are crescent-shaped fibrocartilaginous structures located between the femur (thigh bone) and the tibia (shin bone). They sit atop the tibial plateau and deepen the joint surface, contributing to its stability. Medial meniscus covers most of the articular surface of proximal tibia. Menisci are fibro-cartilage with the peripheral portion vascular and lateral meniscus is more mobile.
MEDIAL MENISCUS :

  1. Location: The medial meniscus is situated on the inner side of the knee joint, between the medial condyle of the femur (thigh bone) and the medial condyle of the tibia (shin bone).

  2. Shape: It is semicircular or crescent-shaped, thicker at the periphery and thinner towards the center.

  3. Attachments:

    • The peripheral rim of the medial meniscus is firmly attached to the joint capsule and blends with the fibers of the medial collateral ligament (MCL).
    • It is also attached to the tibial plateau through coronary ligaments, which stabilize its position.

  4. Clinical Considerations:

Injuries: The medial meniscus is more prone to injury compared to the lateral meniscus due to its anatomical attachments and less mobility. Injuries can occur from sudden twisting motions, sports activities, or degenerative changes over time.

Tears: Common types of tears include longitudinal tears, bucket-handle tears (where a portion flips into the joint), and complex tears involving both the outer rim and inner portion.

Treatment: Treatment for medial meniscus tears depends on the type and severity of the injury. Options range from conservative management (rest, ice, physical therapy) to surgical interventions such as meniscectomy (partial removal) or meniscal repair (suturing the torn meniscus.



Reference-: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition Page no  1406

questions.text: Name the nerve that is indicated by arrow D.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Genitofemoral nerve 

Anatomy:

  1. Origin: The genitofemoral nerve arises from the anterior divisions of the L1 and L2 spinal nerves within the lumbar plexus.

  2. Course: After its origin, the nerve descends through the psoas major muscle and emerges from its lateral border.

  3. Branches:

    • Genital Branch (or Genital Component)
    • Femoral Branch (or Femoral Component)

Function:

  • The Genitofemoral nerve is a mixed nerve.
  • Sensory Innervation: The sensory branch of the Genitofemoral nerve supplies the skin of the upper anterior thigh (femoral branch) and the skin over the scrotum or labia majora (genital branch).
  • Motor Innervation :The motor branch of the Genitofemoral nerve innervates the cremaster muscle in males and the round ligament of the uterus in females.

questions.text:
Following are the landmarks around the knee joint. Injury to which area will cause failure of ankle dorsiflexion?

 
1. B 
2. C 
3. A 
4. D
questions.solution:
Answer (2) C

The given image shows a radiographic film of the knee in the AP view.
  • The key landmarks identified are the lower end of the femur, below which the area of increased opacity represents:
  1. Patella (marked A)
  2. The head of the fibula (marked B)
  3. The neck of the fibula (marked C)
  4. Upper end of the tibia. (marked D)
  • Muscles of the leg consist of an anterior group of extensor muscles, which produce dorsiflexion (extension) of the ankle which receives innervation from the tibial nerve which runs posteriorly across the popliteal fossa, and down the back of the leg. It continues laterally around the neck of the fibula to supply motor and sensory innervation to the leg. Hence injury to the neck of the fibula (option C) would result in failure of dorsiflexion of ankle. 
  • Posterior group of flexor muscles, which produce plantar flexion  & Lateral group of muscles, which evert the ankle both of which are supplied by the superficial and deep peroneal nerves respectively, which are branches of the common peroneal nerve.

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles are supplied by Superior Gluteal Nerve?
A. Gluteus Medius
B. Gluteus Minimus
C. Tensor fascia pata
D. Piriformis
questions.solution:
• The gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fascia lata are innervated by the superior gluteal nerve, while the piriformis is innervated by the nerve to the piriformis.
 
  • The superior gluteal nerve arises from the dorsal branches of the L4, L5, and S1 rami and is accompanied by the superior gluteal vessels. It exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen, above the piriformis, and divides into superior and inferior branches. This nerve supplies the gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fasciae latae.
 
  • The nerve to the piriformis originates from the dorsal divisions of the S1 and S2 rami.
 
  • The gluteus medius and gluteus minimus function as hip joint abductors and help stabilize the pelvis on the femur during walking. This can be assessed by asking the person to stand on one leg. If the ipsilateral abductors are functioning properly, the pelvis remains level. If the abductors are weak, the pelvis tilts towards the opposite (unsupported) side, resulting in a positive Trendelenburg sign.


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st edition, Page no 1318,1330,1374 .

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is diagnosed with left testicular carcinoma. Which of the following lymph nodes is the first to be involved?
questions.solution:
In a patient with testicular carcinoma, the para-aortic lymph nodes are the first to be involved.

The lymphatic drainage of the testes primarily leads to the para-aortic lymph nodes, located near the origin of the gonadal vessels.

While the contralateral para-aortic lymph nodes can also be affected by tumor spread, the inguinal lymph nodes are typically involved only if there is direct tumor invasion of the scrotal skin.


Key points: 
 
Structure Primary Lymph Drainage
Testis Para-aortic (lumbar) lymph nodes, at the level of L1–L2, near the origin of the renal vessels
Scrotal skin Superficial inguinal lymph nodes
Penis Superficial and deep inguinal nodes, then external iliac


Other options: 

  1. Pre-caval nodes – Drainage of kidneys and upper abdomen, not primary for testes.

  2. Iliac nodes – Drain pelvis; involved secondarily if metastasis spreads.

  3. Inguinal nodes – Drain scrotum, not the testis itself.

questions.text: At what time during the intrauterine life does talus ossification center appear?
questions.solution:
Ossification takes place by centres of ossification, each one of which is a point where laying down of lamellae (bone formation) starts by the osteoblasts. The centres of ossification may be primary or secondary. The primary centres appear before birth and secondary centres appear after birth (except distal femur & proximal tibia).
 
In the sixth month of intrauterine life, the ossification core of the talus bone becomes visible.

questions.text: A female patient presents with complaints of pain over the anterolateral aspect of thigh after normal vaginal delivery. Which is the nerve injured in this condition?
questions.solution:
Meralgia paresthetica is indicated by the clinical presentation of a patient presenting with discomfort over the anterolateral side of the thigh suggests involvement of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh.

The posterior divisions of the ventral rami of L2 and L3 are the source of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh, which innervates the skin of the anterior and lateral thighs and extends to the knee.

It is most vulnerable to damage as it leaves the pelvis, just medial to the anterior superior iliac spine, immediately below the inguinal ligament. 

Other options:
1. Femoral: Anterior thigh (motor and sensory)
2. Obturator: Medial thigh
4. Gluteal: Supplies gluteal muscles

questions.text: Identify the tarsal bone labelled in the image below.
questions.solution:
The navicular bone, which sits in between the cuneiforms and the head of the talus, is shown in the picture.

The navicular bone is a tarsal bone located on the medial side of the foot, and it:

  • Lies between the talus (posteriorly) and the three cuneiform bones (anteriorly)

  • Is boat-shaped (hence the name “navicular” from Latin navis, meaning boat)

  • Has a prominent navicular tuberosity on its medial surface, which can be palpated


The proximal part of the foot is home to the seven tarsal bones. The calcaneum and talus make up the proximal row. The cuboid and the medial, intermediate, and lateral cuneiforms are located in the distal row that runs from medial to lateral. The navicular bone sits medially between the cuneiforms and the head of the talus.

Tarsal Bones – Mnemonic (proximal to distal, medial to lateral):

"Tiger Cubs Need MILC"

  • T – Talus

  • C – Calcaneus

  • N – Navicular

  • M – Medial cuneiform

  • I – Intermediate cuneiform

  • L – Lateral cuneiform

  • C – Cuboid



Reference:Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice 41st edition page no 1422-1423

questions.text: Which artery is being palpated in the image shown below?
questions.solution:
In the image described, the artery being palpated lies posterior to the medial malleolus and anterior to the Achilles (calcaneal) tendon. This is the classic anatomical location for palpation of the posterior tibial artery.

  • Posterior tibial artery is palpated:

    • Behind the medial malleolus

    • Anterior to the calcaneal tendon

    • Best felt with slight inversion of the foot to relax the flexor retinaculum


Other options:
 

  • 1. Dorsalis pedis artery: Palpated on the dorsum of the foot, lateral to the extensor hallucis longus tendon—not near the medial malleolus.

  • 2. Popliteal artery: Palpated in the popliteal fossa, behind the knee—not near the ankle.

  • 3. Anterior tibial artery: It courses in the anterior compartment and becomes dorsalis pedis distally—again not behind the medial malleolus.

    Here is a concise table showing different arteries and their palpation locations for quick clinical reference:
     

    Artery Palpation Location
    Radial artery Lateral aspect of the wrist (thumb side), just lateral to the flexor carpi radialis
    Ulnar artery Medial aspect of the wrist, lateral to the flexor carpi ulnaris tendon
    Brachial artery Medial to biceps tendon in antecubital fossa OR mid-arm medial groove
    Axillary artery Deep in the axilla, against the humerus
    Carotid artery Medial to sternocleidomastoid at level of thyroid cartilage
    Femoral artery Midpoint of inguinal ligament (between ASIS and pubic symphysis)
    Popliteal artery Deep in popliteal fossa with knee flexed, between hamstring tendons
    Posterior tibial artery Posterior to medial malleolus, between medial malleolus and Achilles tendon
    Dorsalis pedis artery Dorsum of foot, lateral to extensor hallucis longus tendon
    Temporal artery Anterior to the ear, above the zygomatic arch


Reference:Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice 41st edition page no
1331

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about the basis of functional divisions of the liver ?
questions.solution:
The functional divisions of the liver are based on the portal vein, hepatic artery, and bile ducts, which divide the liver into eight segments. These segments are further grouped into four sectors. The concept of fissures (major or minor) does not accurately describe the basis of these functional divisions.

questions.text: Which of the following is an immune-privileged spot?
questions.solution:
Seminiferous tubules are an immunologically preserved site. Because the sperms produced in them are immunogenic as sperm production occurs after puberty and till then the immune system is matured. Blood- testis barrier provides protection.
The correct answer is option D.

questions.text: The anal canal is not supplied by which of the following vessels?

• Inferior rectal artery and middle rectal artery : Supplies the lower part of the anal canal and originates from the internal pudendal artery.
• Median sacral artery: Supplies the sacrum and coccyx, but not the anal canal directly.

questions.text: What is the most frequent variation in the colon's blood supply?
questions.solution:
The position of right colic artery is highly variable, with its most common origin being a common trunk along with the middle colic artery. It can similarly originate separately from the right side of the superior mesenteric artery, or it may even come from the ileocolic artery in which case it is known as an accessory right colic artery. In some cases, it may even be absent. Variation in position of other arteries are rare.



Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1464.e77

questions.text: Which of the following are not the contents of the mesorectal fascia?
questions.solution:
Mesorectum contains superior rectal artery with its branches, superior rectal vein and its tributaries, lymphatic vessels and nodes that lie along the superior rectal artery, branches from the inferior mesenteric plexus which descend to innervate the rectum and loose adipose connective tissue. Inferior rectal vein is not a content of mesorectum.



Reference-: https://radiopaedia.org/articles/mesorectal-fascia

questions.text: Which part of the fallopian tube acts as a physiological sphincter?

Intramural part: narrowest part serving as anatomical sphincter, Isthmus: 2nd narrowest part of fallopian tube serving as physiological spincter.



Reference-: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition Page no 22

questions.text: What is the most vital source of blood for the stomach?
questions.solution:
Most important blood supply to the stomach is the left gastric artery.

The left gastric artery is the branch of the celiac axis andis the largest artery supplying the stomach.

Blood Supply of Stomach:

 
  • Left gastric artery:Branch of celiac trunk (Largest) 
  • Right gastric artery: Branch of hepatic artery
  • Right gastroepiploic artery: Branch of gastroduodenal artery 
  • Left gastroepiploic artery: Branch of splenic artery
  • Short gastric arteries: Branch of splenic artery



Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1164,1165

questions.text: What nerves innervate the external anal sphincter?
questions.solution:
External anal sphincter is innervated by inferior rectal branch of pudendal nerve (anterior divisions of S2, S3, S4 sacral spinal nerves) mainly and by perineal branch of S4.

Pudendal nerve is the main sensory motor nerve of the perineum and sensory nerve of the genitalia.




Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1464.e42,1201

questions.text: Which of the following doesn't have a mesorectal fascia covering?
questions.solution:
Inferior rectal vein is not enclosed in mesorectal fascia.

Contents of Mesorectal fascia:

  •  Superior rectal artery and its branches
  •  Superior rectal vein and tributaries
  •  Lymphatic vessels and nodes along superior rectal artery.
  •  Branches from inferior mesenteric plexus to innervate rectum
  •  Loose adipose connective tissue down to the level of levator ani (pelvic floor)


Reference: https://radiopaedia.org/articles/mesorectal-fascia

questions.text: The urethra's elevation, known as the urethral crest, is caused by:
questions.solution:
Urethral crest is an elevation seen in the urethra due to trigonal muscles. 

In males, the urethral crest is known as the crista urethralis masculinae and is a longitudinal fold on the posterior wall of the urethra extending from the uvula of the bladder through the prostatic urethra. It contains muscular and erectile tissue. When distended, it may serve to prevent the passage of the semen backward into the bladder.

In females, it is known as the crista urethralis femininae, and is a conspicuous longitudinal fold of mucosa on the posterior wall of the urethra.


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1278

questions.text: Pick the option that does not contribute to the formation of anorectal ring in human beings?
questions.solution: Anorectal Ring is a muscular ring present at the anorectal junction. It is formed by the fusion of the Puborectalis, the uppermost fibers of the external sphincter, and the internal sphincter. Thus Anococcygeal raphe does not contribute to its formation.

choices.text: Release of catecholamines is not affected by nerve supply to adrenals
Preganglionic fibres from lower thoracic and lumbar vertebra come via sympathetic chain to supply adrenals
Adrenal cortex doesn't have nerve supply as it has endocrine functions

questions.text: What is accurate about the adrenal gland's nerve supply?
questions.solution:
The adrenal glands hold mostly preganglionic sympathetic nerve impulses that start in the lower thoracic segments of the spine, with branches from the coeliac system and plexus, as well as through the greater splanchnic nerve.

The suprarenal gland, relative to its size, has a larger autonomic supply than any other organ. On each side, the suprarenal plexus lies between the medial aspect of the gland and the celiac and aorticorenal ganglia. It contains mostly preganglionic sympathetic fires, which originate in the lower thoracic spinal segments and which reach the plexus via branches from the coeliac ganglion and plexus, and via the greater splanchnic nerve.

Other options:- 

  • Release of catecholamines is affected by the sympathetic nervous system 
  • Adrenal cortex and medulla both have nerve supply




Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1239-1242

questions.text: The hypogastric sheath is a condensation of the following:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Pelvic fascia
 
  • The hypogastric sheath, also known as the rectovesical fascia in males or the rectouterine fascia in females, is a structure found in the pelvic region.
  • It is formed by a condensation or thickening of the pelvic fascia, which is a connective tissue layer in the pelvis.
  • The pelvic fascia provides support and serves as a compartmentalizing structure for various organs in the pelvis.

Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18920874/

questions.text: Urogenital Diaphragm is not made up of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Colle's fascia
 
  • The urogenital diaphragm is a muscular layer in the perineum that separates the pelvic cavity from the external genitalia.
  • It is made up of the deep transverse perineal muscle, the perineal membrane, and the sphincter urethrae.
  • Colle's fascia is a layer of superficial fascia that covers the perineum.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about the iliolumbar ligament?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Upper attachment to transverse process of T12
 
  • The iliolumbar ligament is a strong band of fibrous tissue that connects the iliac crest to the transverse process of L5 and the base of the sacrum.
  • It helps to stabilize the lumbosacral joint and prevent excessive movement of the lumbar spine.
  • The iliolumbar ligament does not have an attachment to the transverse process of T12 (twelfth thoracic vertebra). Instead, its upper attachment is to the posterior part of the iliac crest, as mentioned in statement A.
  • The lower fibers are attached to the base of the sacrum.


Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1366,1367

questions.text: What keeps the uterus from being anteverted?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Round The structure that keeps the uterus from being anteverted (tilted forward) is the Round ligament. The Round ligaments are paired ligaments that extend from the uterine horns to the labia majora. During pregnancy, the round ligaments help support the uterus in its anteverted position.



Reference: https://radiopaedia.org/articles/spermatic-cord-contents-mnemonic

questions.text: The ligation of the common hepatic artery impair blood supply to which arteries
questions.solution:
Ligation of the common hepatic artery will impair blood supply in the right gastric and right gastroepiploic arteries because the common hepatic artery is the main supply of blood to both arteries. Without it, blood flow to the two arteries will be significantly reduced, decreasing the oxygen and nutrient supply to the organs they supply, potentially leading to tissue death.





 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1464.e74,1464.e75,1168

questions.text: A man was brought to the emergency after meeting with an accident and injured his perineum. He gets an urge to micturate but its unable to pass urine. On examination blood was seen at tip of urethra and swelling of penis and scrotum. Locate the site of injury among the following:
questions.solution:
A ruptured bulbar urethra is an injury that occurs when there is severe blunt force trauma to the pelvis or groin area. Symptoms include perineal bruising and hematoma, bleeding from the urethral meatus, and difficulty passing urine. Diagnosis is typically confirmed through urethrography using a water-soluble contrast agent. Initial management involves inserting a suprapubic catheter to drain the bladder, in order to reduce the chance of urinary extravasation and sepsis in the perineal hematoma. In more severe cases, delayed urethroplasty is typically done as the definitive treatment.



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery 28th Edition Page no: 1520,1540-1

questions.text: The following lymph nodes get lymphatic drainage from the spongy urethra:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Deep inguinal nodes 
 
  • The spongy urethra, also known as the penile urethra, is part of the male urethra that runs within the penis.
  • It is lined with stratified columnar epithelium and receives lymphatic drainage from the deep inguinal nodes.
  • The deep inguinal nodes are located along the femoral vein in the femoral canal and receive lymphatic drainage from the spongy urethra, the glans penis, the penile skin, and the scrotum.

  



Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1283

questions.text: Identify the nerve highlighted by the red box in the given image
questions.solution:
The structure highlighted by the red box is ischial spine and it is related to the internal pudendal nerve. 

It is a branch of sacral plexus-S2S3S4 and it exits from the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen. Thereafter, it enters the perineum below the pelvic floor by passing around ischial spine through the lesser sciatic foramen. 

The ischial spine serves as an important landmark for pudendal nerve block. 

Note- The structures passing the lesser sciatic foramen can be remembered by the mnemonic PINT

P- Pudendal nerve
I- Internal pudendal vessels
N-Nerve to obturator internus
T-Tendon of obturator internus


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1147,1199,1252

questions.text: Identify the pelvic diaphragm in the image below.
questions.solution:
Pelvic diaphragm is a muscular bed which gives support to the pelvic viscera and closes the pelvic outlet.

It is formed by the levator ani and coccygeus. Nerve Supply is by pudendal nerve (Root : S2, S3, S4).

questions.text: What is the obstruction that stops the spleen from falling vertically in a patient whose costal border had splenomegaly measuring 15 cm?
questions.solution:
The phrenicocolic ligament continues below and supports the spleen from the left colic flexure to the thoracic diaphragm opposite the tenth and eleventh ribs.
The phrenicocolic ligament, which marks the location where the colon leaves the peritoneal cavity, is an essential point of junction of abdominal anatomy and, as a result, a key location for the spread of abdominal diseases.



Reference-: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition Page no 1189

questions.text:
A little child was admitted to the hospital by his father due to a fever, a low backache, and chronic hip flexion.
He has already experienced spine TB. The infant has an inguinal swelling upon inspection. Which indicated muscle is likely to be involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: a
 
  • The inguinal swelling in the image is caused by the psoas abscess extending into the inguinal canal.
  • The psoas major muscle is the most likely muscle to be involved in this case because it is the muscle that is most affected by psoas abscess.
  • Psoas abscess is most commonly caused by infection from the spine, such as from spine TB.
  • The infection can spread to the psoas major muscle through the intervertebral foramina.
   



Reference-: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery Edition 28 th Page No 1104

questions.text: Choose the best way to gauge an adult's nasogastric tube length.
questions.solution:
Nasogastric tube ( Ryle’s tube ) is used for administration of drugs, oral agents and feeding. It can also be used for Nasogastric aspiration. The length required is calculated as the distance from nose to tragus of ear to the tip of xiphoid process.

Process of insertion of Ryles Tube: -
1. Lubricate Ryles tube with lignocaine jelly
2. Ask the patient to flex his neck 45 degrees in sitting position
3. Slowly insert the tube through nose and ask patient to take sips of water
4. Check the proper insertion by auscultation and aspiration technique
5. Secure the tube by taping it




Reference-:https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC10439641/

questions.text: Which among the following does not constitute a part of the superficial perineal pouch?
questions.solution:
The Sphincter urethrae is not a component of the superficial perineal pouch. It's a component of the deep perineal pouch.  

Superficial Perineal Pouch 

It's the space between the perineal membrane and the deep membranous layer of superficial fascia. 

Boundaries of Superficial Perineal Pouch 

Inferior:  Membranous layer of the superficial fascia.
Superior: Perineal Membrane.
Lateral:  Ischiopubic rami.

Contents of Superficial Perineal Pouch 
 
  • Root(Crura) of penis/clitoris and muscles associated (Ischicavernous)
  • Bulb of penis/vestibule and muscles associated (Bulbospongiosus)
  • Corpus cavernosum and spongiosum
  • Ducts of bulbourethral(male)/greater vestibular glands(female)
  • Superficial Transverse perineal muscle
  • Branches of the internal pudendal artery (posterior scrotal/labial artery and vein
  • Artery to bulb (males)/vestibule (females)
  • Branches of the pudendal nerve(posterior scrotal/labial nerve)



Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1256,1257

questions.text: Which of the following arteries receives blood from the superior mesenteric artery?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery
 
  • Inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery is the only artery that receives blood from the superior mesenteric artery, and it supplies blood to the head of the pancreas and the duodenum.
  • The other answer choices, the gastroduodenal artery, the superior pancreaticoduodenal artery, and the left gastroepiploic artery, are all branches of the celiac artery.

questions.text: Which fascia runs along the cremasteric muscle in the scrotum?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Fascia from internal oblique 
 
  • The cremaster muscle is a thin layer of muscle that covers the testis and spermatic cord in the scrotum.
  • It is responsible for raising the testis in response to cold temperatures. The cremasteric muscle is covered by a fascia that is derived from the fascia of the internal oblique muscle. This fascia is called the cremasteric fascia.
  • It is derived from the fascia of the internal oblique muscle of the abdominal wall.
  • The fascia from the internal oblique muscle runs along the cremasteric muscle in the scrotum.

  


 

Reference-:Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice 42 nd Edition Page No 1298

questions.text: The level of the posterior superior iliac spine is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: S2
 
  • The posterior superior iliac spine (PSIS) is a bony landmark located on the posterior aspect of the iliac bone, which is one of the bones that make up the pelvis.
  • It is used as a reference point in anatomical and medical assessments.
  • The PSIS is found at the level of the second sacral vertebra (S2). It is situated slightly above the gluteal fold on each side of the lower back.

 



Reference-: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition Page No 748, 978

questions.text: The fascia of Zuckerkandl in relation to the kidney describes:
questions.solution:
Correct Option 3: Posterior fibrous sheath
 
  • The fascia of Zuckerkandl is a fibrous sheath or layer located posteriorly (at the back) to the kidney.
  • It is also known as the posterior renal fascia or posterior fibrous sheath.
  • This fascial layer plays a crucial role in supporting and stabilizing the kidney in its anatomical position within the retroperitoneal space (the space at the back of the abdominal cavity).
  • The anterior fibrous sheath and paranephric fat are other structures around the kidney, but they are not specifically referred to as the fascia of Zuckerkandl.




Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1137

questions.text: Except for_________, all of  the following structures passes via the female inguinal canal.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Inferior Epigastric Artery
  • The inguinal canal is a passage in the lower abdominal wall that is present in both males and females.
  • It contains various structures, including nerves, blood vessels, and ligaments.
  • Inferior Epigastric Artery does not pass through the inguinal canal. It arises from the external iliac artery and supplies the anterior abdominal wall.

Other options:
  • Ilioinguinal nerve: This nerve passes through the inguinal canal in both males and females.
  • Round ligament of uterus: This ligament passes through the inguinal canal in females and helps to anchor the uterus within the pelvis.
  • Lymphatics from the uterus: Lymphatic vessels from the uterus can pass through the inguinal canal in females.


Reference-:https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470204/

questions.text: Which of the following claims regarding "Valves of Houston" is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Valves disappear after mobilization of Rectum
 
  • The valves of Houston are semilunar folds of the rectal wall that are formed by the muscularis propria of the rectum.
  • The muscularis propria is a layer of smooth muscle that forms the wall of the rectum.
  • During mobilization of the rectum, the muscularis propria is separated from the surrounding tissue. This separation results in the disappearance of the valves of Houston.
Other options: -
  • Middle valve corresponds to the middle convex fold to left
  • The middle valve corresponds to peritoneal reflection

questions.text: Where does the supraduodenal bile duct's primary blood supply come from?
questions.solution:
Bile duct/ common bile duct is divided into four parts-
1. Supraduodenal part
2. Retroduodenal part
3. Infraduodenal(or pancreatic) part
4. Intraduodenal part

Arterial supply-
Upper part of bile duct is supplied by a twig from the descending branch of cystic artery.
Middle part is supplied by the right hepatic artery.
Lower part is supplied by the ascending branch of the gastroduodenal and superior pancreaticoduodenal arteries.



Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1219-1220,1464.e75

questions.text: Except for _______, all of the following structures cross the right ureter anteriorly.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Genitofemoral nerve
 
  • Except for the genitofemoral nerve, all of the other structures listed cross the right ureter anteriorly.
  • The genitofemoral nerve runs posteriorly to the right ureter, while the terminal ileum, vas deferens, and right colic and ileocolic vessels cross the right ureter in an anterior fashion.
  • The genitofemoral nerve is a nerve that arises from the lumbar plexus and descends into the pelvis.
  • It then divides into two branches, the genital branch, and the femoral branch.
  • The structures that cross the right ureter anteriorly are the terminal ileum, vas deferens, and right colic and ileocolic vessels.
  • However, the genitofemoral nerve does not cross the right ureter anteriorly.

questions.text: Due to the rupture of the bulbar urethra, urine enters all these spaces except?
questions.solution:
When the bulbar urethra ruptures, typically due to trauma, urine can extravasate into the superficial perineal pouch. From there, it can spread to the following areas:

  • Scrotum
  • Penis
  • Anterior abdominal wall (beneath Scarpa's fascia)

However, urine does not enter the deep perineal space, as the deep perineal fascia (also called the perineal membrane) acts as a barrier separating the superficial and deep perineal compartments.



Reference: Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 42nd edition, Page no 1299, 1255, 1256.

questions.text: In a patient with liver cirrhosis, anastomosis between which of the following will be seen?
questions.solution:
Answer: (1). Left gastric vein and esophageal vein

A patient suffering from liver cirrhosis is likely to have portal hypertension.
  • Patients with obstructed portal blood flow, are likely to have significant collateral circulation which occurs through sites of portocaval anastomoses/ communications - one of them being left gastric and esophageal veins.
  • In patients with portal hypertension, there is increased blood flow through these channels, leading to dilation. They may present with complications such as variceal bleeding, or hemorrhoids, and are thus clinically significant.
The following are sites of portocaval anastomosis:




Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition, Page. No- 1167.

questions.text:
The marked structure ‘X’ represents a defect in which of the following?

1. Internal Oblique
2. Fascia Transversalis
3. Transversus Abdominis
4. External Oblique
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Fascia Transversalis


The structure marked by ‘X’ represents the deep inguinal ring. The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the Fascia Transversalis. 

The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the transversalis fascia, approximately midway between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic symphysis, and about 1 cm above the inguinal ligament. It is oval, with a roughly vertical long axis. Its size varies between individuals but it is usually 1–2 cm wide in adults and larger in the male. It is related above to the arched lower margin of transversus abdominis and medially to the interfoveolar ligament.

*  Relation of Deep Inguinal Ring: 



Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition, Page. No- 1080.

questions.text: Weakness of which of the following can cause a hernia superior to the pubic tubercle and medial to the inferior epigastric artery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Conjoint Tendon

The vignette describes a hernia present superior to the pubic tubercle. (Inguinal hernia)

  • The weakness of the conjoint tendon, which forms the posterior wall of the inguinal canal and guards the superficial inguinal ring, will predispose to direct inguinal hernias.
  • The conjoint tendon is formed from the lower fibres of internal oblique and the lower part of the aponeurosis of transversus abdominis. It is attached to the pubic crest and extends to a variable extent along the pectineal line. It descends behind the superficial inguinal ring and acts to strengthen the medial portion of the posterior wall of the inguinal canal. Medially, the upper fibres of the tendon fuse with the anterior wall of the rectus sheath, and laterally, some fibres may blend with the interfoveolar ligament.
     




Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition, Page. No- 1078.

questions.text: 75y old female with abdominal pain and swelling presented to the surgical casulty.On examination tense and tender swelling found below and lateral to pubic tubercle. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a tense and tender swelling present lateral and below the pubic tubercle is suggestive of a femoral hernia, the femoral hernia traverses the femoral canal which lies medial to the femoral vein.
All the patients with unexplained bowel obstruction should be examined thoroughly for a femoral hernia, surgery is the mainstream treatment for femoral hernia and these patients should be treated on priority basis because of high risk of strangulation.
Swelling which is below and lateral to pubic tubercle is suggestive of femoral Hernia- Since it is tense and tender more likely to be strangulated femoral hernia.
Treatment- Low approach- Lockwood , High Approach -McEvedy.

Adhesions- History of surgery/ with no abdominal swelling

questions.text: Anterior relations of the third part of the duodenum are all except:
questions.solution:
• The anterior relations of the third part of the duodenum include the superior mesenteric vessels, the root of the mesentery, and loops of the jejunum.
  • Posterior relations of the third part of the duodenum are the right ureter, right psoas major, right gonadal vessels, the inferior vena cava, and the abdominal aorta (near the origin of the inferior mesenteric artery).
  • Anteriorly, it is related to loops of the jejunum, the root of the mesentery, and the superior mesenteric vessels.
  • It is superiorly related to the head of the pancreas and inferiorly to loops of the jejunum.


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st edition, Page no 1126.

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles form the pelvic diaphragm?
A. Iliococcygeus
B. Pubococcygeus
C. Obturator internus
D. Deep transverse perinei
questions.solution:
lliococcygeus and pubococcygeus are parts of the pelvic diaphragm, which is also known as the levator ani.

The levator ani muscle is a complex unit that consists of 3 muscle components:
  1. Pubococcygeus
  2. Pubovaginalis – elevates the urethra and hence contributes to urinary continence
  3. Puboperinealis – draws the perineal body towards the pubic symphysis
  4. Puboanalis – elevates the anus and keeps the urogenital hiatus narrowed
  5. Puborectalis
  6. Iliococcygeus
 
  • Levator ani muscles are the most important muscles in the pelvic floor and maintain a constant state of contraction.
  • They provide a stable floor and support the weight of the abdominopelvic contents against intra-abdominal forces.
  • Weakening of levatorani and pelvic fascia from stretching or tearing during childbirth, may decrease support for the vagina, bladder, uterus, or rectum or alter the position of the neck of the bladder and urethra.

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 25 .

questions.text: Identify the given histology slide:
questions.solution:
The image depicts pancreatic islet cells, also known as the islets of Langerhans, which make up the endocrine component of the pancreas.

These islets are composed of secretory cells supported by reticulin fibers and contain numerous fenestrated capillaries. Each islet is surrounded by a delicate capsule and appears paler than the surrounding exocrine cells due to having less rough endoplasmic reticulum.
The islets of Langerhans are made up of four major and two minor cell types:

Major cell types:

α (A) cells: Located peripherally, they secrete glucagon.
β (B) cells: Located centrally, they produce insulin.
Delta (D) cells: Scattered between beta cells, they secrete somatostatin.
PP cells: Present in both the islets and exocrine pancreas, they secrete pancreatic polypeptide, which influences gastrointestinal functions, including the stimulation of gastric and intestinal enzymes and the inhibition of intestinal motility.

Minor cell types:
D1 cells: Secrete vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP), which induces glycogenolysis, hyperglycemia, and gastrointestinal fluid secretion, contributing to secretory diarrhea.
Enterochromaffin cells: Produce serotonin and are implicated in pancreatic tumors that lead to carcinoid syndrome.
