questions.text: Identify the maneuver shown :
questions.solution:
Pringle's maneuver, which is used to promptly stop bleeding from the portal vein and hepatic artery in the event of liver trauma or surgery, is shown in the picture. Stopping blood flow from the hepatic artery and portal vein involves compressing the free edge of the lesser omentum (known as hepatoduodenal ligament which contain the portal vein and hepatic artery).
This maneuver helps differentiate bleeding from the hepatic artery or portal vein, which will stop on clamping the hepatoduodenal ligament.But hepatic vein bleeding, which will continue.
Once bleeding is controlled, the liver laceration can be explored, and any actively bleeding vessels can be sutured and ligated.



The management of liver injuries involves the "4 P's":
1. Push: Compressing the edges of the laceration
2. Pringle
3. Plug: using Sengstaken-Blakemore tube
4. Pack: packing around the liver using gauze or laparotomy pads to maintain hemostasis

other options
1. Mattox manoeuver: left-sided medial visceral rotation of abdominal organs, used in trauma to expose the abdominal aorta
2. Cattell-Braasch maneuver: right-sided medial visceral rotation to expose inferior vena cava


Reference :
1.Sabiston Textbook of Surgery 20th Edition - Page no 439, 444
2. Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery - 27th Edition - Page-374

questions.text: Which of the following forms the lateral boundary of the femoral triangle?
questions.solution:
The femoral triangle boundaries are:

  • Lateral: Medial margin of sartorius

  • Apex: Point where sartorius crosses adductor longus

  • Floor: Iliopsoas (laterally), pectineus (medially)

  • Roof: Fascia lata

So the lateral boundary is formed by the medial margin of sartorius.

questions.text: Which of the following layers is absent in esophagus?
questions.solution:
GI tract has four layers throughout its length, except in esophagus which lacks the serosa layer.
 

The esophagus wall layers (from inside out):

  1. Mucosa – stratified squamous non-keratinized epithelium, lamina propria, muscularis mucosae

  2. Submucosa – with esophageal glands

  3. Muscularis externa –

    • Upper 1/3: skeletal muscle

    • Middle 1/3: mixed

    • Lower 1/3: smooth muscle

  4. Adventitia (not serosa) – except the short abdominal part (which has serosa)

So generally, the esophagus lacks serosa along most of its course (has adventitia instead).





Reference
Inderbir Singh Textbook of Human Histology 8th Edition , Page no. 176

questions.text: The structure used to demarcate upper gastrointestinal bleeding and lower gastrointestinal bleeding is_.
questions.solution:
• The Ligament of Treitz (also called the suspensory muscle of the duodenum) marks the junction between the duodenum and jejunum — specifically the duodenojejunal flexure.

  • It serves as the anatomical landmark to distinguish:

    • Upper GI bleeding: Proximal to the ligament (e.g., esophagus, stomach, duodenum)

    • Lower GI bleeding: Distal to the ligament (e.g., jejunum, ileum, colon)

      Incorrect Options:

    • Ampulla of Vater: Marks the junction where the bile and pancreatic ducts empty into the duodenum.

    • Hepatic flexure: Junction between ascending and transverse colon.

    • Splenic flexure: Junction between transverse and descending colon.



Reference: Sabiston textbook of surgery 20th edition Page no 1139

questions.text: Select the position that best describes the location of celiac plexus.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Anterolateral to aorta
 
  • The celiac plexus is a network of nerves located in the abdomen, near where the celiac trunk, superior mesenteric artery, and renal arteries branch from the abdominal aorta.
  • It is behind the stomach and the omental bursa, and in front of the crura of the diaphragm, on the level of the first lumbar vertebra.
  • The celiac plexus is anterolateral to the aorta, meaning that it is located in front of the aorta and to the side.
  • The sympathetic chain is a group of nerves that runs alongside the aorta, and the celiac plexus is located anterior to the sympathetic chain.

questions.text: The superior vena cava empties into:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Right Atrium
 
  • The superior vena cava is a large vein that carries deoxygenated blood from the upper half of the body to the heart.
  • It collects blood from various veins, including the brachiocephalic veins, which drain blood from the head and arms, and the azygos vein, which drains blood from the thoracic wall.
  • The superior vena cava then enters the upper-right part of the heart and directly empties its deoxygenated blood into the right atrium.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the anatomy of the breast?
questions.solution:
• The breasts are paired structures located on the anterior thoracic wall, in the pectoral region. The breast lies in the superficial fascia of the pectoral region.
  • It is divided into four quadrants, i.e upper medial, upper lateral, lower medial and lower lateral.
  • Vertically, it extends from the second to the sixth ribs.
  • Horizontally, it extends from the lateral border of the sternum to the midaxillary line.
  • A small extension of the upper lateral quadrant, called the axillary tail of Spence, passes through an opening in the deep fascia and extends across the anterior axillary fold extends across the anterior axillary fold.
  • Fibrous strands or sheets consisting of condensations of connective tissue extend between the posterior lamina of the superficial fascia and the dermis.
  • These suspensory ligaments (retinacula or Cooper's ligaments) are often well-developed in the superior parts of the breast and support the breast tissue, helping to minimize drooping.
  • The breasts normally comprise up to 20 discrete lobes that contain ductal-glandular tissue consisting of branching ducts and terminal secretory lobules in a connective tissue stroma.
  • Each lobe is derived by branching from one central lactiferous duct in the nipple, The terminal duct lobular unit (TDLU or lobule) is the functional milk secretory component of the breast.
Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice,42nd Edition, Page No 1013.

questions.text: Identify the anatomical variation in the given CT
questions.solution:
The CT finding in the image is suggestive of an aberrant right subclavian artery.

An aberrant right subclavian artery (ARSA) is a rare congenital abnormality of the aortic arch that occurs when the right subclavian artery originates from the aortic arch instead of the brachiocephalic artery.

Course: The artery then runs behind the esophagus to reach the right side. Symptoms: About 30% of patients with ARSA experience symptoms, such as dysphagia, cough, dyspnea, and chest pain. However, most patients are asymptomatic.






Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page No 877.

questions.text: In the given barium swallow image, which of the following shows the left atrium impression on the esophagus?
questions.solution:
In the barium swallow image, the arrow labeled with the number 3 indicates the impression of the left atrium on the esophagus.

The esophagus is a fibromuscular tube that connects the pharynx to the stomach, traversing the thorax through the superior and posterior mediastinum. It begins below the cricopharyngeus muscle, at the level of C6, specifically at the lower margin of the cricoid cartilage. Positioned behind the trachea in the neck, the esophagus descends posterior to the left main bronchus, left atrium, and aortic arch, each of which creates an impression on its surface.

As the esophagus travels down through the diaphragm at the T10 level, the vagus nerves accompany it, terminating at the gastric cardia at T11. The left lobe of the liver is located anteriorly to the abdominal segment of the esophagus. The esophagus consists of a short cervical portion, a long thoracic portion, and a short abdominal segment.

questions.text: Which of the following structures passes through the foramen marked by the arrow?
questions.solution:
The arrow points to the aortic hiatus of the diaphragm, through which the thoracic duct passes.

The diaphragm contains multiple openings that allow structures to transition between the thorax and abdomen. Among these, three major openings are prominent: the aortic hiatus, esophageal hiatus, and caval hiatus, along with several smaller openings.

questions.text: On palpation at the site marked by the red arrow on the image a bony ridge is felt. What is the vertebral level of the marked arrow?
questions.solution:
A body ridge palpable a few centimeters from the suprasternal notch corresponds to the angle of Louis (sternal angle). Recent data indicate that the sternal angle is located between the T4 vertebra and the upper half of the T5 vertebra in most adults.

The mediastinum is divided into superior and inferior sections by an imaginary line connecting the sternal angle to the T4-T5 intervertebral disc.

Traditionally, the sternal plane is described as passing through the intervertebral disc between the T4 and T5 vertebrae posteriorly and the manubriosternal joint (angle of Louis) at the level of the second costal cartilage anteriorly. This plane serves as an anatomical landmark for various structures within the mediastinum.

questions.text: What form does the trapezius muscle have?
questions.solution:
Trapezius is a triangular muscle.

The flat, triangular muscle known as the trapezius protects the back of the neck and shoulder. When the two trapezius muscles are combined, they resemble a trapezium or quadrilateral, where the shoulders are represented by two of the angles, the occipital protuberance by the third, and the 12th thoracic vertebra's spine by the fourth.

It is innervated by the 11th cranial nerve along with sternocleidomastoid muscle.

questions.text: Which of the following is the normal curvature of lumbar spine?
questions.solution:
Lordosis is normally seen in the lumbar spine.
 
  • The forward curve in the neck (cervical spine) and lower back ( lumbar spine ) known as lordosis is considered normal. 
  • The backword curvature exhibited in the chest (thoracic spine) and hip regions is known as normal kyphosis (sacral spine).
  • A knee malformation known as genu recurvatum causes the knee to bend backwards.

questions.text: What makes up the ligamentum flavum?
questions.solution:
The ligamentum flavum has a high content of elastin.
 
  • The ligamentum flavum has so much elastin that it is always under tension and may be stretched by 80% without suffering any harm.
  •  This ligament most likely serves to keep the spinal canal continuously smooth, never overstretched in flexion, and never relaxed in extension.

questions.text: The presence of what allows the cervical vertebra to be distinguished from the thoracic vertebra:
questions.solution:
The cervical vertebrae can be distinguished from the thoracic vertebrae by the presence of foramina transversaria. This foramen allows nerves and vessels to pass through.

A typical cervical vertebra possesses a small, wide body; a large, triangular vertebral canal; superior articular facets facing backwards and upwards; inferior articular facets facing downwards and forwards; and the presence of a foramen transversarium.

The second part of the vertebral artery usually passes through the transverse processes of the vertebrae from C1 to C6, with C7 being the exception.


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 418,828

questions.text: Which of these is accurate regarding the space pointed by green arrow in the given figure:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Breath sound can be heard more clearly 

The marked arrow indicates the triangle of auscultation.
The marked area is the triangle of auscultation.
Boundaries include-
• Medially by the lateral border of the inferior part of trapezius.
• Laterally by the vertebral border of the scapula.
• Inferiorly by the superior border of latissimus dorsi muscle.
Importance-
• Only part of back which is covered by muscles.
• Respiratory sounds are better heard when ausculted here.
The triangle of auscultation refers to a specific anatomical region on the human body where lung sounds can be best heard. It is an area where there is less muscle and fat coverage, allowing for clearer auscultation of respiratory sounds. Here’s how you can locate it:

  • Position: Stand or sit comfortably with your back exposed.

  • Location: The triangle itself is located roughly between the scapula (shoulder blade) and the latissimus dorsi muscle. Specifically, it is an imaginary triangle-shaped area with its base along the bottom edge of the scapula and its apex pointing towards the lower ribs.

  • Purpose: This area is important for auscultation (listening with a stethoscope) because the underlying lung tissue is closer to the surface here, allowing healthcare providers to hear respiratory sounds such as normal breathing sounds (vesicular breath sounds) or abnormal sounds like crackles or wheezes more clearly.

  • In clinical practice, this region is particularly useful for detecting abnormalities in lung sounds and for assessing respiratory function in patients.



    Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 843,852

  • Latissimus Dorsi originates from the thoracic and lumbar vertebrae, and it inserts into the upper arm bone (humerus).

questions.text:
Which of the statements given below regarding the muscle shown in the image are correct?



A. They elevate the scapula along with fibres of Trapezius
B. They retract the scapula along with the middle fibres of Trapezius

MUSCLES INVOLVED IN MOVEMENT OF SCAPULA
 
  • ELEVATION - Levator scapulae, Trapezius and Rhomboids. 
  • DEPRESSION - Gravity, if further - Pectoralis Minor/Serratus anterior and Trapezius.

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with an abnormal gait. On examination, when the patient was asked to stand on the left foot, a right-sided hip drop was observed. Which of the following muscles are paralyzed in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient's examination reveals a positive Trendelenburg's sign (Trendelenburg's gait), characterized by sagging on the right side. This sign indicates paralysis of the left gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscles, which are innervated by the left superior gluteal nerve.

Function of the Gluteus Medius and Minimus:

The gluteus medius and minimus muscles are responsible for stabilizing the pelvis. When the leg on one side is lifted off the ground, these muscles on the opposite side exert force on the hip bone, acting from the femur. This action raises the pelvis slightly on the unsupported side, helping to maintain the trunk in an upright position.

If the gluteus medius and minimus are paralyzed, the pelvis will dip down on the unsupported (normal) side when the patient attempts to stand on the affected limb, resulting in the positive Trendelenburg sign.

questions.text: To what level of vertebrae does the marked structure correspond?
questions.solution:
The structure indicated in the image is the umbilicus, which corresponds to the anatomical level of the junction between the third and fourth lumbar vertebrae (L3 and L4).

Innervation:

The skin surrounding the umbilicus is supplied by the thoracic spinal nerve T10, corresponding to the T10 dermatome.

Clinical Significance:

  • Used as a landmark for lumbar puncture (which is typically done at L3–L4 or L4–L5).

  • Corresponds roughly to the level of the T10 dermatome (important in spinal anesthesia and dermatome mapping).

    Structures Crossed by the Transumbilical Plane:

    Used to Divide Abdomen:
    The transumbilical plane, when combined with the median plane, divides the abdomen into four quadrants:

  • Right upper quadrant (RUQ)

  • Left upper quadrant (LUQ)

  • Right lower quadrant (RLQ)

  • Left lower quadrant (LLQ)

questions.text: The following image displays numerous foramina at the base of the skull. Which of the following foramina does the mandibular nerve pass through?

questions.text: Which of the following structures is seen in the centre of the cavernous sinus?
questions.solution:
Internal carotid artery with its surrounding sympathetic plexus and abducens nerve, are the contents of cavernous sinus. Maxillary division of V nerve, Mandibular division of V nerve, Internal carotid artery and Trochlear nerve are seen in the cavernous sinus, but ICA lies inside (in the centre of the sinus, while the other three lie in the lateral wall of the sinus

questions.text: Which one of the following muscles is not supplied by the trigeminal nerve?
questions.solution:
The stylohyoid originates on the back side of the styloid process in close proximity to its base. It extends to the body of the hyoid bone at the point where it intersects the greater cornu. It is supplied by the stylohyoid branch of the facial nerve, which often appears in tandem with the digastric branch then entering into the midsection of the muscle.It is innervated by the stylohyoid branch of the facial nerve.

questions.text: Find the structure in this figure whose paralysis results in a reduction in breathing motions.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: A
 
  • The structure in the figure that is labeled A is the phrenic nerve.
  • The phrenic nerve is responsible for innervating the diaphragm, which is the major muscle of breathing.
  • The phrenic nerve carries motor signals from the brain to the diaphragm, stimulating its contraction and promoting inhalation.
  • Paralysis of the phrenic nerve will result in a reduction in breathing motions and may result in respiratory difficulties or even respiratory failure, depending on the extent of the nerve damage.
  The other structures in the figure are the following:
  • B: Thyrocervical artery
  • C: Inferior thyroid artery
  • D: Vagus nerve

questions.text: Pick the option that does not contribute to the formation of the facial recess in human beings.
questions.solution:

questions.text: Which of the following nerves, when damaged, affects lacrimation?
questions.solution: The greater petrosal nerve is a branch of the facial nerve, which arises from the geniculate ganglion, and ultimately supplies the lacrimal gland along with mucosal glands of nose, palate, and pharynx. Damage to it will deprive the lacrimal gland from its secretomotor fibers and this would lead to the absence of tears, along with other complications.

questions.text: The inferior thyroid artery is a branch of:
questions.solution:
The thyrocervical trunk is a broad, short artery that originates from the front of the first portion of the subclavian artery next to the medial border of scalenus anterior and quickly splits into the inferior thyroid, suprascapular and superficial cervical arteries.

The inferior thyroid artery supplies the lower pole of thyroid gland along with parathyroid gland.

questions.text: What is the vocal cord tensor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Cricothyroid
 
  • The cricothyroid muscle is the only muscle that can tense the vocal cords.
  • The cricothyroid muscle connects the cricoid cartilage (a ring-shaped cartilage) to the thyroid cartilage (an anteriorly located cartilage in the larynx).
  • It does this by pulling the cricoid cartilage forward, which increases the distance between the vocal processes of the arytenoid cartilages.

questions.text: Acute tonsillitis effects which of the following nerve?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Glossopharyngeal Nerve
 
  • Acute tonsillitis is an inflammation or infection of the tonsils, which are located at the back of the throat.
  • The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) is responsible for providing sensory innervation to the back of the throat, including the tonsils.
  • The glossopharyngeal nerve also plays a role in the gag reflex and taste sensation from the posterior third of the tongue.

questions.text: Which of the options below traverses the magnum foramen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Vertebral artery The foramen magnum is a large opening at the base of the skull through which the spinal cord exits the skull and becomes the spinal canal. The vertebral artery is an important blood vessel that supplies the brain and spinal cord with oxygenated blood. The vertebral artery travels through the foramen magnum to enter the cranial cavity. Once inside the cranial cavity, the vertebral arteries join together to form the basilar artery, which is a critical part of the brain's blood supply.

Other options:-
  • Sympathetic chain and Internal carotid artery pass via Foramen Lacerum
  • CN 11 passes via Jugular Foramen

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 418

questions.text: The water's view is used to get diagnostic data on:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Maxillary sinus
 
  • The Waters' view is a radiographic view of the skull that is commonly used to get a better view of the maxillary sinuses.
  • During the Water's view X-ray, the patient's head is positioned with the forehead and nose against the X-ray film or detector.
  • An x-ray beam is angled at 45° to the orbitomeatal line.
  • The rays pass from behind the head and are perpendicular to the radiographic plate.

  




Reference:P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and neck surgery 8th Edition Page no 509

questions.text: Which thickened nerve is visible in the picture?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Great auricular nerve
 
  • The great auricular nerve is a cutaneous nerve that supplies sensation to the skin of the ear and the side of the neck. It is a branch of the cervical plexus.
  • The great auricular nerve is often thickened in people with leprosy, a chronic infectious disease that affects the skin, nerves, and limbs.
  • The facial nerve, vagus nerve, and glossopharyngeal nerve are all cranial nerves that supply the head and neck. They are not visible in the picture.
  • The picture shows a person with probably leprosy, and the thickened nerve is the great auricular nerve.

questions.text: What is the purpose of Caldwell's view?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Frontal sinus
 
  • The Caldwell view is primarily used to assess the frontal sinuses
  • It can also be used to assess the ethmoidal sinuses and the superior portion of the maxillary sinuses. However, it is not as effective for visualizing the maxillary sinuses as the Waters' view.
  • During the Caldwell's view X-ray, the patient's head is positioned with the chin raised, and the X-ray beam is directed through the patient's skull from below the face.
  • Caldwell's view is particularly useful in assessing the frontal sinuses for any abnormalities or signs of sinusitis, sinus infections, or other sinus-related conditions
  


 

Reference:P L Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat and Head and neck surgery 8th Edition Page no 509

questions.text: The following is not a extrinsic laryngeal membrane/ligament:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Cricothyroid 
 
  • Extrinsic laryngeal ligaments are those that attach the larynx to other structures in the neck, such as the hyoid bone and the thyroid cartilage.
  • Intrinsic laryngeal ligaments are those that connect the different cartilages of the larynx to each other.
  • The cricothyroid ligament is an intrinsic laryngeal ligament, not an extrinsic laryngeal ligament.

questions.text: Coughing is caused by external auditory canal stimulation and involves which nerve?
questions.solution:
The Auricular branch of Vagus nerve, known as Arnold's Nerve, supplies the concha (the pocket in the external ear), the posterior wall and floor of the external ear canal. Stimulation of the Vagus nerve during probing can lead to a cough reflex or even a slowing of the heart rate (bradycardia). Interestingly, there are also sensory fibers of facial nerve that supply the posterior wall and concha of the external ear through the Vagus nerve fibers. Therefore, when a person has herpes zoster oticus, which is a virus that affects the facial nerve, vesicles may be seen on the concha and the postauricular region.



Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1035.e1

questions.solution:
Pretracheal layer of deep cervical fascia encloses all except sternocleidomastoid.

Sternocleidomastoid is enclosed by investing layer of deep cervical fascia. 

The anterior visceral space, also known as the pretracheal space in surgery and radiology, is enclosed by the visceral division of the middle layer of the deep cervical fascia. questions.text: Which of the following supplies the dilator pupillae?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Post-ganglionic sympathetic fibres from cervical sympathetic chain
 
  • The dilator pupillae muscle is responsible for dilating the pupil of the eye and is part of the iris.
  • The control of the pupil size involves both sympathetic and parasympathetic fibers.
  • Post-ganglionic parasympathetic fibers from the Edinger-Westphal nucleus travel in the oculomotor (III) cranial nerve and innervate the sphincter pupillae muscle, which causes pupillary constriction (miosis).
  • Post-ganglionic sympathetic fibers from the cervical sympathetic chain travel through the sympathetic pathway and innervate the dilator pupillae muscle, causing pupillary dilation (mydriasis).

  


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 781

questions.text: Which of the following movements of the mandible involves the involvement of the inferior compartment of the temporomandibular joint?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Elevation
 
  • The temporomandibular joint (TMJ) is a complex joint responsible for the movement of the mandible (lower jaw).
  • It consists of two compartments: the superior compartment and the inferior compartment.
  • The inferior compartment of the temporomandibular joint (TMJ) is involved in the rotational movement of the mandible, which is known as elevation. This is the movement of the mandible when the mouth closes.
  • The other choices, protrusion, retraction, and translation, are all movements that involve the superior compartment of the TMJ.





Reference: https://www.physio-pedia.com/TMJ_Anatomy

questions.text: Select the extraocular muscle that causes lateral movement [abduction] and elevation of eye ball.
questions.solution:
Correct Option 2:Inferior oblique
  • The extraocular muscle responsible for causing lateral abduction and elevation of the eyeball is the inferior oblique muscle.
  • This muscle is one of the six muscles that control the movements of the eye and is responsible for rotating the eye upward and outward (lateral abduction) when it contracts.
EXTRAOCCULAR MUSCLES AND MOVEMENTS :

  • Medial Rectus Muscle: Located on the nasal side of the eye. When it contracts, it pulls the eye medially (towards the nose), causing adduction (moving the eye inward).

  • Lateral Rectus Muscle: Located on the temporal side of the eye. When it contracts, it pulls the eye laterally (towards the temple), causing abduction (moving the eye outward).

  • Superior Rectus Muscle: Located above the eye. When it contracts, it pulls the eye upward, causing elevation (moving the eye upward) and slight adduction.

  • Inferior Rectus Muscle: Located below the eye. When it contracts, it pulls the eye downward, causing depression (moving the eye downward) and slight adduction.

  • Superior Oblique Muscle: Originating from the back of the orbit, it passes through a pulley-like structure (trochlea) before inserting on the sclera. When it contracts, it primarily rotates the eye downward and laterally (extorsion).

  • Inferior Oblique Muscle: Originating from the orbital floor near the nose, it inserts on the sclera near the lateral rectus muscle. When it contracts, it primarily rotates the eye upward and laterally (intorsion).



    Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 774

questions.text: The floor of the region enclosed by the dotted black line is made up of
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Splenius capitis
 
  • The dotted black line in the image encloses the posterior triangle of the neck.
  • The posterior triangle is a triangular space in the neck that is bounded by the trapezius muscle superiorly, the sternocleidomastoid muscle medially, and the clavicle inferiorly.
  • The floor of the posterior triangle is made up of the levator scapulae, middle layer of the deep cervical fascia, and the splenius capitis muscle.

 


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 550,575,576

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is associated with branchial cyst?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Anterior border of sternocleidomastoid
 
  • A branchial cyst is a cystic swelling that arises from the persistence of embryonic branchial clefts or pouches.
  • These clefts are derived from the embryonic pharyngeal arches.
  • The cysts are usually found along the course of these embryonic clefts or pouches.
  • The anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle is associated with the first branchial cleft.

Reference-: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery 28th Edition Page no 805

questions.text: Which of the following muscles contains the "gateway of tears"/Killian Dehiscence?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Inferior constrictor of the pharynx

Killian Dehiscence: This refers to a weakness or defect in the posterior wall of the pharynx, specifically between the inferior constrictor muscle and the cricopharyngeus muscle.
This area is located in the hypopharynx (part of the pharynx just above the esophagus) and is susceptible to the formation of a diverticulum or pouch called a Killian's or Killian-Jamieson diverticulum.
This diverticulum can form due to increased pressure during swallowing, leading to a herniation of the mucosa through the weak spot causing Zenker's Diverticulum.



 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1464e.153,1464e,162,712

questions.text: What are Delphin lymph nodes?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Pre-laryngeal
 
  • The Delphian lymph node is a small lymph node that is located anterior to the larynx, between the cricoid and thyroid cartilages.
  • It is also known as the prelaryngeal or cricothyroid node.
  • The Delphian lymph node receives lymph from the thyroid gland and the larynx.
  • It is important in the staging of thyroid cancer, as metastasis to the Delphian lymph node is a sign of advanced disease.
 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 730

choices.text: Recurrent laryngeal nerve and External laryngeal nerve
Internal laryngeal nerve and External laryngeal nerve
Superior laryngeal nerve and Internal laryngeal nerve

questions.text: Which nerves are connected by Galen's anastomosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Recurrent laryngeal nerve and Internal laryngeal nerve
 
  • Galen's anastomosis is a communication between the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) and the internal laryngeal nerve (ILN).
  • It is located on the dorsal surface of the larynx, near the cricoarytenoid joints.
  • The RLN is a branch of the vagus nerve that supplies motor innervation to the intrinsic muscles of the larynx.
  • The ILN is a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve that supplies sensory innervation to the larynx.





 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 730

questions.text: Which of the following muscles in the palate is NOT innervated by the vagus nerve's pharyngeal branch, which travels through the pharyngeal plexus, and the cranial portion of the accessory nerve?

Tensor veli palatini: This muscle in the palate is innervated by the mandibular nerve (V3), which is a branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V).

questions.text: Which is an exception to the muscles of Tongue?

Palatoglossus:

  • It is part of the palate and functions in elevating the back of the tongue during swallowing, rather than directly moving the body of the tongue.

questions.text: The position of the thyroid is determined by which of the following vertebral levels?
questions.solution:
The thyroid gland, a butterfly-shaped endocrine gland, is located in the anterior neck, spanning the level of vertebrae C5-T1 - hence , the closest answer here is C6-T1 i.e. option 2. 



Other important levels
Thyroid Cartilage:  C4-C5
Cricoid cartilage: C6
Isthmus of Thyroid Gland - 2nd/3rd cartilaginous rings of trachea (Not C2/C3 vertebrae!)

questions.text: Which of the following does not provide the pinna with sensory supply?

  • It does not provide sensory supply to the pinna.

questions.text: What is meant by Whitnall's ligament?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Superior transverse ligament of the eye
 
  • Whitnall's ligament is the Superior transverse ligament of the eye.
  • It is a fibrous band that attaches to the superior rectus muscle tendon sheath, the medial side of the trochlea, and to the lateral orbital margin..
  • It supports and stabilizes the superior rectus muscle, one of the extraocular muscles responsible for eye movement.
  • Helps maintain the proper position and function of the superior rectus muscle during eye movements.

questions.text: Which of these is not a branch of the facial artery?
questions.solution:
• The mental artery is not a branch of the Facial Artery.  It's a terminal end branch of the inferior alveolar artery. 
  • The maxillary artery gives rise to the inferior alveolar artery, which in turn gives off the mental artery as its end branch.


Reference : Gray’s Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition - page no 454,498,499 .

questions.text: Which among the following is formed by 3 bones?
questions.solution:
• Foramen Magnum is a large opening in the base of the skull that is formed by the occipital bone and allows the spinal cord to pass through.
  • Jugular Foramen is a foramen located at the base of the skull, formed by the temporal and occipital bones, which allows the passage of the internal jugular vein and cranial nerves IX, X, and XI.
  • Foramen Rotundum is a small, circular foramen in the sphenoid bone of the skull, which is formed by the greater wing of the sphenoid bone, and allows the passage of the maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V2).
  • Foramen Lacerum is a jagged opening located at the base of the skull, formed by the sphenoid, temporal, and occipital bones, which is filled with cartilage in life and allows the passage of blood vessels and nerves.
Hence, Foramen Lacerum is formed by three bones. 





Reference : Gray’s Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition - page no 422,423,430 .

1. XIIth Nerve
2. IXth Nerve

questions.text: A medical student was yawning during his afternoon anatomy lecture. His jaw was arrested while yawning. Which muscle is attached to the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Lateral Pterygoid.

Yawning involves a wide opening of the mouth. Opening of the mouth involves active depression (downward movement) and this movement is brought about mainly by the contraction of the lateral pterygoid.

  • In the wide opening of the mouth, this hinge-like movement is followed by gliding of the disc and the head of the mandible in the upper compartment.
  • At the end of this movement, the head comes to lie under the articular tubercle. Thus, in this medical student, the arrest of yawning occurs likely due to failure of the gliding forward of the articular disc by the lateral pterygoid.





Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition, Page. No- 547.

questions.text: A patient presented with progressive pain and swelling anterior to the left ear lobule. Which anatomical structure is responsible for pain?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (option 4) Investing Layer of Deep Cervical Fascia

The vignette mentions a patient presenting with a swelling anterior to the left ear lobule, which is painful/ tender. This is likely to indicate a swelling of the parotid gland. 
  • The investing layer of the deep cervical fascia forms a capsule for the gland. 
  • Parotid swellings are very painful due to the unyielding nature of the parotid fascia, and thus, the most appropriate answer to the question is the investing layer of the deep cervical fascia.
  • The capsule of the parotid gland formed by the fascia is innervated by the great auricular nerve and skin over the gland is supplied by the great auricular nerve (C2, C3). (Option C)

#Controversial: Due to the variability in the exact wording of the recall question and options, this question remains controversial. But, Option D is preferable over Option C, since parotid swellings are painful due to the firm nature of the fascia.
If the question had which structure was responsible for the transmission of pain - then option (C) would be better. 


Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition, Page. No- 477, 505.

questions.text:
A patient presented to the OPD with inflammation of the tonsils. The patient also had pain in the ipsilateral ear. Which nerve is responsible for the pain in the ear due to tonsillitis?

1. Auricular Branch of X nerve
2. Tympanic Branch of IX nerve
3. VII Nerve
4. V Nerve
questions.solution:
Answer: (2). Tympanic Branch of IX nerve

Due to the shared innervation by the glossopharyngeal nerve, the pain of tonsillitis can be referred to the glossopharyngeal nerve which gives sensory supply to the inner surface of the tympanic membrane, the middle ear, the auditory tube, the mastoid antrum, and air cells. 

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, P.L. Dhingra, 8th Edition, Page No 149.

questions.text: A 60 year old male patient is brought to the ER due to a suspected stroke. The patient has difficulty forming words but can make noises and give expressions as if he understands the questions asked. Which type of aphasia is most likely present in the patient?
questions.solution:
•The given clinical scenario is suggesstive of Broca's aphasia. In Broca's aphasia/ Motor aphasia/ Non- fluent aphasia, areas 44 and 45 in the prefrontal and premotor facial regions of the cerebrl cortex are affected. The affected individuals will have difficulty forming verbal and written words. the comprehension aspect of speech is preserved but the person cannot repeat or name the words and lacks fluency. Other options:

• Wernicke's aphasia is a type of fluent aphasia in which comprehension is impaired. The speech is easy and fluent but it is full of jargon and neologisms(non-existent words) that make little sense. Damage to the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus(area 22) or blockade of the inferior division of the middle cerebral artery causes Wernicke's aphasia

• Global aphasia- In this, both understanding and speaking are impaired. It is also non-fluent aphasia.

• Conduction aphasia is seen in lesions of the arcuate fasciculus, the bundle of nerve fibres connecting the Wernicke and Broca's areas. Repetition of words is impaired and paraphasias are observed, though not as much as in Wernicke aphasia.

Broca's and Wernicke's areas can be seen in the image below:

questions.text: The image below shows the cross-section of the trachea. Identify the structure marked (7)
questions.solution:
The structure marked 7 is Trachealis muscle.

The trachea is a tubular structure that facilitates the passage of air between the larynx and the bronchi. The trachealis muscle, located at the posterior wall of the trachea, is composed of smooth muscle and connects the ends of the C-shaped tracheal cartilage rings, completing the posterior part of the tracheal wall.

In a histological section of the trachea, the following structures can be observed:
  1. Lumen
  2. Mucosa (pseudostratified epithelium)
  3. Submucosa
  4. Hyaline cartilage
  5. Adventitia
  6. Seromucous gland
  7. Trachealis muscle


A higher magnification reveals the following

 
  1. Lumen
  2. Mucosa (pseudostratified epithelium)
  3. Submucosa
  4. Hyaline cartilage
  5. Adventitia
  6. Seromucous gland

questions.text: What is the embryological origin of the labelled structure?
questions.solution:
The malleus (along with the incus) develops from the cartilaginous (Meckel’s cartilage) part of the first pharyngeal arch.

Embryological derivatives of the first arch:

  • Skeletal: Malleus, incus, mandible, maxilla, zygomatic bone, part of temporal bone

  • Muscles: Muscles of mastication (masseter, temporalis, pterygoids), mylohyoid, anterior belly of digastric, tensor tympani, tensor veli palatini

  • Nerve: Mandibular division of trigeminal nerve (CN V‚ÇÉ)

The stapes, in contrast, arises from the second pharyngeal arch (Reichert’s cartilage).

Thus, the malleus is derived from the first pharyngeal arch.

questions.text: The common caritid artery pulse is assessed at the level of?
questions.solution:
The common carotid artery pulse is typically palpated at the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle, at the level of the angle of the mandible.

Key points:

  • Carotid artery anatomy:

    • Right common carotid arises from brachiocephalic trunk, left from aortic arch.

    • Runs upwards in the neck alongside the trachea and esophagus.

  • Palpation site:

    • Just medial to the sternocleidomastoid muscle, at the level of the thyroid cartilage or angle of mandible.

    • Care must be taken not to palpate both sides simultaneously to avoid carotid sinus-mediated bradycardia or syncope.

Other options:

  • Suprasternal notch: Lower neck, not ideal for pulse.

  • Laryngeal prominence: Level of thyroid cartilage, slightly lower than mandible.

  • Cricoid cartilage: C6 level, more inferior.

questions.text: Which of the following arteries passes in close proximity to the area marked by the arrow in the given image?
questions.solution:
The middle meningeal artery (MMA) is a branch of the maxillary artery that enters the cranial cavity through the foramen spinosum.

Key points:

  • It runs in close proximity to the temporal fossa and pterion region (junction of frontal, parietal, temporal, and sphenoid bones).

  • Clinical relevance:

    • The pterion is the thinnest part of the skull, and trauma here can rupture the MMA, causing an epidural hematoma.

  • Other arteries:

    • Internal carotid artery: Runs in the cavernous sinus and carotid canal, deeper and medial.

    • Anterior cerebral artery: Part of the circle of Willis, intracranial, medial surface of frontal lobes.

    • Deep temporal artery: Branch of maxillary artery supplying temporalis muscle, not near the cranial vault.

choices.text: Recurrent Laryngeal nerve and Superior larygeal artery
Leavator veli palitini and Superior laryngeal nerve

questions.text:
Match the following:
Column I Column II
1 Facial nerve A Shrugging of shoulder
2 Spinal accessory nerve B Taste from anterior two third of the tongue
3 Glossopharyngeal nerve C Taste from posterior one-third of the tongue
4 Mandibular nerve D Chewing
questions.solution:
1. **Facial nerve** - B. Taste from anterior two-thirds of the tongue
2. **Spinal accessory nerve** - A. Shrugging of shoulder
3. **Glossopharyngeal nerve** - C. Taste from posterior one-third of the tongue
4. **Mandibular nerve** - D. Chewing
Chorda tympani nerve which is a branch of facial nerve carries taste from anterior 2/3rd of the tongue.

The trapezius is innervated by the spinal accessory nerve (CN XI). It causes retraction of scapula, shrugging of the shoulder and overhead abduction (along with serratus anterior). Paralysis of trapezius causes drooping of the shoulder and slight winging of the scapula (the superior angle of scapula becomes more prominent).

The glossopharyngeal nerve carries taste sensation from the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue.

The mandibular nerve (V3) is responsible for chewing movements as it gives motor supply to muscles of mastication. It contains both sensory and motor fibers.

Sensory from
Skin of cheek, over mandible and side of head
Teeth of lower jaw and temporomandibular joint
Mucous membrane of mouth and anterior
Part of tongue

Motor to
E Muscles of mastication (pterygoids, masster and temporalis)
Tensor tympani
Anterior belly of digastric
Mylohyoid
MCQ

 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st edition, Page no 232,501,502,810 .

questions.text: The nerve supply of larynx above the level of the vocal cords is by
questions.solution:
The larynx is supplied by branches of the vagus nerve (CN X):
 
Laryngeal Region Nerve Supply Branch of
Above the vocal cords (including the laryngeal inlet, vestibule, epiglottis) Internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve Vagus nerve
Below the vocal cords Recurrent laryngeal nerve Vagus nerve
Cricothyroid muscle (only intrinsic laryngeal muscle not supplied by recurrent laryngeal) External branch of superior laryngeal nerve Vagus nerve

Clinical Relevance:
 

  • Injury to the internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve during procedures like thyroid surgery may result in loss of sensation above the vocal cords, increasing aspiration risk.

  • Recurrent laryngeal nerve injury affects phonation due to paralysis of vocal cord muscles.

questions.text: A patient presents with a cyst on the neck anterior to the sternocleidomastoid at the junction of the upper and middle third of the muscle. This cyst is due to the persistence of which of the following embryological clefts?
questions.solution:
A branchial cyst typically presents at the junction of the upper and middle thirds of the sternomastoid muscle, along its anterior border. It originates from the vestigial remnants of the second branchial cleft.

The cyst is usually lined by squamous epithelium and contains a thick, turbid fluid filled with cholesterol crystals. It is fluctuant and may only partially transilluminate if the fluid is clear.

Classic branchial (lateral cervical) cyst: painless swelling anterior to SCM at the junction of upper & middle thirds, from persistence of the 2nd branchial cleft/cervical sinus.
(Tract, if present, typically runs to the tonsillar fossa.)



A branchial fistula may be either congenital or acquired.

A congenital fistula is found at the junction of the middle and lower thirds of the sternomastoid muscle.

An acquired fistula often results from incomplete surgery on a branchial cyst or spontaneous rupture and is usually located at the same site as the cyst.

choices.text: Upper 2/3rd is bony and lower 1/3rd is cartilaginous
Upper ½ is bony and lower ½ is cartilaginous

questions.text: Framework of external nose:
questions.solution:
• The external nose is supported by both bone and cartilage.

  • Upper 1/3rd → bony framework (nasal bones, frontal process of maxilla, nasal part of frontal bone).

  • Lower 2/3rd → cartilaginous framework (upper & lower lateral cartilages, septal cartilage, alar cartilages, and minor cartilages).

questions.text: A 70 year old uncontrolled diabetic presented with blackish nasal discharge and proptosis of right eye followed by proptosis involving the left eye. On imaging she was found to have cavernous sinus thrombosis. Which of the following structures are not involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
Cavernous sinus syndrome (CSS) is a rare condition characterized by ophthalmoplegia, proptosis, ocular and conjunctival congestion, trigeminal sensory loss, and Horner's syndrome. The cavernous sinuses are two large venous plexuses that lie on either side of the body of the sphenoid bone. Structures related to the lateral wall of the cavernous sinuses are the occulomotor nerve(CN3) trochlear nerve(CN 4),ophthalmic nerve(V1) branch of trigeminal nerve and the maxillary nerve branch of the trigeminal nerve(V2).The Abducens nerve and cavernous part of internal carotid artery lie within the substance of the cavernous sinus. The V3 division of the trigeminal nerve does not get affected in cavernous sinus thrombosis syndrome.

Ref- Grays Anatomy 42nd edition Page 403

questions.text: A patient had his molar teeth extracted following which, he developed loss of general sensation in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. Which of the following nerves is likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
Tongue has two types of sensations: general sensations and taste. Tongue is divided into anterior 2/3 and posterior 1/3 based on nerve supply.
Anterior 2/3: general sensations by Lingual nerve, and taste carried by chorda tympani nerve( branch of facial nerve)
posterior 1/3: both taste and general sensations carried by glossopharyngeal nerve.

The question states loss of general sensations in anterior 2/3 of tongue hence answer is Lingual nerve.



Other options:
1. Hypoglossal nerve: Motor to tongue muscles (no sensory function)
2. Inferior alveolar nerve: Supplies mandibular teeth
3. Glossopharyngeal nerve‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã: General and special sensation from posterior 1/3 of tongue

Reference
Gray's Anatomy. The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition , Page nos 514 and 528

questions.text: From which structures do the alae of the nose develop?
questions.solution:
Ala of nose develops from Lateral nasal process.

Since ala is a lateral structure of nose, hence the answer can be derived from the options. Medial structures such as tip and crest of nose including nasal septum will be derived from medial nasal process. Bucconasal membrane – It separates the nasal cavity from the oral cavity

questions.text: A patient sustained an injury to the head and now presents with blood collected around his eyes. Attachment of which of the following structure leads to this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical manifestation of blood collection around the eye as black eye or raccoon eye (because of lood seeping into the periorbital connective tissue).

Injury to the scalp (especially above the aponeurosis) causes blood to collect in the loose areolar tissue layer.
Since the aponeurosis is attached firmly to the upper eyelid, blood can track anteriorly into the eyelids, causing periorbital bruising.

Scalp Layers (Mnemonic: SCALP)
S – Skin
C – Connective tissue (dense)
A – Aponeurosis (galea aponeurotica)
L – Loose areolar tissue
P – Pericranium


Reference :
Gray's Anatomy. The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition, Page no 475, 1588

questions.text: A 39 year old patient presents to the OPD with complaints of pain over his ear lobule. He also complains of difficulty in eating food and the inability to close his eyes completely. On examination, there is a swelling below his ear. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with:
1. Pain over ear lobule
2. Difficulty eating (suggests facial muscle involvement)
3. Inability to close eyes (orbicularis oculi weakness)
4. Swelling below the ear (likely parotid gland)

All these point toward facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) involvement, likely due to inflammation or tumor of the parotid gland, which houses the intraparotid plexus of the facial nerve.



Other options

Reference
Gray's Anatomy. The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st Edition , Page no. 630-635

questions.text: Identify the structure marked as 'C'.
questions.solution:
The structure marked as 'C', is the Epiglottis.

The structures marked in the image are:

A. Hyoid bone
B. Thyroid cartilage
C. Epiglottis
D. Cricoid cartilage

The laryngeal skeleton is formed by a series of
cartilages that are connected by ligaments and
fibrous membranes:

* The thyroid, cricoid, and the greater part of the arytenoid cartilages consist of hyaline cartilage.

* The corniculate, cuneiform, tritiate, and epiglottic cartilages and the apices of the arytenoid cartilage consist of elastic cartilage.

* The hyoid bone is a ‘U-shaped' bone suspended from the tips of the styloid processes by the stylohyoid ligaments.

      Unpaired cartilages (3):


      Mnemonic: “TEC”

  • Thyroid – made of hyaline cartilage

  • Epiglottis – made of elastic cartilage

  • Cricoid – made of hyaline cartilage

    Paired cartilages (3 pairs):

         Mnemonic: “ACC”

  • Arytenoid – made of hyaline cartilage

  • Corniculate – made of elastic cartilage

  • Cuneiform – made of elastic cartilage


Reference:Grays Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice 41st edition page no 586

questions.text: The image below shows the cross-section of the trachea. Identify the structure marked
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image shows the muscle of trachealis.

The trachea is a tubular structure which allows air to pass between the larynx and the bronchi. The trachealis muscle is a smooth muscle in the posterior wall of the trachea. It connects the ends of the C-shaped cartilage rings of the trachea and completes the posterior part of the tracheal wall. A tissue section of the trachea shows the following structures:

* Respiratory epithelium

* Basement membrane

* Submucosal glands (serous and mucous parts)

* Perichondrium

* Tracheal cartilage

* Tracheal muscle (smooth muscle).

Reference:Inderbir Singhs Textbook of human histology 8th edition chapter 13 page 152-153

questions.text: Pick the nerve nucleus that underlies the facial colliculus.
questions.solution:
The facial colliculus is present on the floor of the 4th ventricle. It's formed by the looping of facial fibers over the abducens nerve nucleus. Hence, the Facial colliculus overlies the abducens nucleus.

   



Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1464.e17,410

choices.text: Infection can spread to cavernous sinus from danger area of face via inferior ophthalmic vein

questions.text: Which of these is not true about the cavernous sinus thrombosis:
questions.solution:
The jaw jerk reflex is unaffected in the case of Cavernous Sinus Thrombosis because both the afferent and efferent sensations are carried by the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve which lies outside of the cavernous sinus.

However, it does lead to loss of sensation around the eye due to the involvement of the ophthalmic branch present in the lateral wall of the sinus. It most commonly spreads through ethmoid sinus and can spread from danger area of face via Inferior ophthalmic vein. 

    


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 403,404,700,1464.e102

questions.text: Pick the correct nerve that doesn't pass through the foramen marked in the picture.
questions.solution:
The arrow points towards Foramen Ovale, present in the sphenoid bone.
Contents of Foramen ovale include: Trick- MALE

  • Mandibular Nerve (Sensory and motor branch)
  • Accessory Meningeal Artery
  • Lesser Petrosal Nerve
  • Emissary Vein from Cavernous sinus.
The maxillary nerve instead passes through the Foramen Rotundum(not foramen ovale) present in the base of the greater wing of the sphenoid bone.


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 566,567,232

questions.text: What is housed by the 'Turkish saddle'?
questions.solution:
• ‚ÄãTurkish Saddle AKA Sella Turcica is the saddle-shaped fossa in the sphenoid bone that houses the Pituitary Gland.

questions.text: What would be the likely deficit if the area marked below gets affected?
questions.solution:
• The frontal lobe, which houses the Broca's region, is where the arrow in this illustration is pointing. Despite being mostly on the lateral side of the brain, this region extends all the way to the medial surface. Aphasia results from this area being affected.

questions.text: Select the muscle that is supplied by the cranial nerve nucleus present beneath the area marked by the arrow below.
questions.solution:
The arrow in the given diagram points towards floor of fourth ventricle and towards Facial Colliculus. 
Facial colliculus is an elevated area located in the dorsal pons.
It is formed by fibres from the facial motor nucleus looping over the abducens(VI) nucleus

The 6th cranial nerve supplies the Lateral Rectus muscle.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure 'A' in the image?
questions.solution:
Marked structure in the given image is the posterior commissure.

Commissural fibers forming the rostrum extend laterally, below the anterior horn of the lateral ventricle, connecting the orbital surfaces of the frontal lobes.

Fibers in the genu curve forwards, as the forceps minor, to connect the lateral and medial surfaces of the frontal lobes.

questions.text: Identify the marked nerve shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Abducent nerve is the marked nerve in the illustration.

When the abducent nerve leaves the brainstem, it moves into the subarachnoid area. It ascends between the pons and the clivus before piercing the dura mater and passes via Dorello's canal to run between the dura and the skull.

It turns sharply forward at the point of the petrous temporal bone to enter the cavernous sinus.


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 445

questions.text: Which cranial nerve nucleus is closest to the facial colliculus in depth?
questions.solution:
The facial colliculus is made of motor nerve fibers of the facial nerve looping over the CN VI nerve nucleus and this looping of fibers over the abducens nerve nucleus forms a bump upon the surface. It's present on the floor of the 4th ventricle.

questions.text: Which of the following does not have general visceral efferent fibers?
questions.solution:
There are no general visceral efferent fibers  ( parasympathetic )  in the olfactory nerve.

9th nerve-Inferior salivary nucleus

questions.text: The section of the brain is shown below with a region highlighted. What pathology will result from a defect in this area?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Paralysis agitans
 
  • The highlighted area in the image is the substantia nigra, which is a part of the basal ganglia.
  • The basal ganglia are a group of nuclei in the brain that are involved in movement, learning, and emotion.
  • Parkinson's disease (paralysis agitans) is a neurodegenerative disorder that is caused by the loss of dopamine-producing neurons in the substantia nigra.
  • Symptoms of Parkinson's disease include tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia, and postural instability.

   



Reference:https://www.britannica.com/science/Parkinson-disease

questions.text: Which of the following structures connects to the arrow-marked structure in the illustration?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Amygdala
 
  • The amygdala is the small, almond-shaped structure in the middle of the illustration.
  • It is located in the temporal lobe of the brain.
  • It is involved in the processing of emotions, particularly fear and aggression.
  • The tail of the caudate nucleus is the arrow-marked structure at the bottom of the illustration.
  • The stria terminalis is the bundle of nerve fibers that connects the amygdala to the tail of the caudate nucleus.

   


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 518-520.e1

questions.text: Which of the following is inhibited by the axon of the neuron pointed with an arrow in this cross-sectional image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Cerebellar nuclei
 
  • The arrow is showing purkinje fibers.
  • In the central nervous system, Purkinje cells in the cerebellum play a crucial role in inhibiting the activity of cerebellar nuclei.
  • This inhibitory control helps modulate and fine-tune the output signals of the cerebellum.
  • Purkinje cells contribute to the coordination and smooth execution of voluntary movements.
  • Therefore, the axons of Purkinje cells inhibit cerebellar nuclei, aiding in motor coordination.
 


 



 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 468-470

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of occlusion of the artery supplying the marked area?
questions.solution:
The marked area is the paracentral lobule.
 
  • This region controls voluntary urination and defecation as well as the movements of the contralateral lower leg and perineum.
  •  Hence, blockage of the artery feeding the paracentral lobule can result in perianal analgesia, urinary incontinence, and rectal incontinence but not apraxia.
Apraxia results from damage to dominant parietal lobe. 


Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 512
https://radiopaedia.org/articles/paracentral-lobule

questions.text: Identify the highlighted nerve in the given cranial cavity section.
questions.solution:
The marked structure in the image of cranial cavity is oculomotor nerve. It is the third cranial nerve. 
  • Four of the extraocular muscles are innervated by it: the superior, inferior, medial, and inferior oblique muscles. Moreover, it carries parasympathetic fibers that relay in the ciliary ganglion.
  • The nerve begins at the midbrain, medial to the cerebral peduncle's crus, and travels along the lateral cavernous sinus wall before splitting into superior and inferior divisions that pass below the trochlear and ophthalmic nerves.


Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 391,563,566

questions.text: Which of the following cranial nerves does not relate to smell?
questions.solution:
Hypoglossal (XII) nerve is a motor nerve; does not play the role in olfaction and gustation.

The hypoglossal nerve is the motor supply to all the muscles of the tongue ,except palatoglossus.


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 644

questions.text: Which of the following cannot lead to a right trochlear nerve palsy?
questions.solution:
Trochlear nerve palsy typically manifests with specific symptoms related to the affected eye’s movement and alignment, such as diplopia on upward gaze and adduction, and compensatory right head tilt to alleviate symptoms. Hyperopia (farsightedness) does not directly cause a trochlear nerve palsy; instead, it affects visual acuity due to the way light focuses on the retina, and it is not associated with the specific ocular motor deficits characteristic of a trochlear nerve palsy.


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 774,775

questions.text: In the diagram, identify the nerve whose palsy causes lateral gaze palsy.
questions.solution:
The sixth cranial nerve (abducens nerve), which supplies the lateral rectus muscle, is what causes lateral gaze palsy and it travels within the sinus in close relation with the internal carotid artery.
Hence the answer is option ‘B’

Other options:
A. Occulomotor nerve
C. Trochlear nerve
D. Ophthalmic branch of Maxillary nerve

questions.text: Identify the control center for the stapedial reflex from following nerve roots.
questions.solution:

Pathway - High intensity auditory stimulus reaches the cochleae, neural impulses from the auditory nerves ascend from both cochleae to each ipsilateral ventral cochlear nucleus (VCN), then from the VCN to the superior olivary complex (SOC) before the impulses cross at the brainstem to innervate both ipsilateral and contralateral facial motor nuclei.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Dura Mater is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Dural venous sinuses lie between outer endosteal and inner meningeal layers hence outer to the meningeal layer and not inner. Thus it is a false statement. Rest all are true. The outermost layer of the meninges is known as the duramater, or pachymeninx. It is continuous with the spinal duramater through the foramen magnum, and is separated into two distinct layers: an external endosteal layer and an internal meningeal layer. The latter two layers meet, but separate at points around the venous sinuses that transfer blood away from the brain and the bones within the cranium. The endosteal layer is connected with the cranial sutures and foramina, as well as the orbital periosteum via the superior orbital fissure.


Reference-: https://radiopaedia.org/articles/dura-mater

questions.text: Which of the following arteries does not supply blood to the medulla?
questions.solution:

Anterior spinal artery supplies the median area of Medulla and PICA supplies the lateral part of medulla. The Superior Cerebellar Artery, however, is not a branch of the Vertebral Artery. The Superior cerebellar artery arises close to the terminal bifurcation of the basilar artery and supplies the cerebellum's cortex, white matter, and central nuclei.

questions.text: Which of the following does not get secretomotor fibres from the facial nerve?

Submandibular and sublingual glands are supplied by the submandibular ganglion, with preganglionic fibres arising from the superior salivatory nucleus and passing through the facial nerve. questions.text: What causes thrombosis in the posterior inferior cerebellar artery?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Lateral medullary syndrome

questions.text: 50y old male presents with loss of sensation over the right side of face and sensory symtoms over left side of the body. What is the most likely localisation of the lesion?
questions.solution:
Lateral medullary infarction (also known as Wallenberg syndrome) is a stroke that occurs when one of the Vertebral artery > Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery that supply blood to the medulla oblongata in the brain is suddenly blocked.
Symptoms of the syndrome typically include unconsciousness, dizziness, vertigo, nausea, Ipsilateral ataxia, bulbar palsy, loss of temperature and pain sensation of face and contralateral loss of pain and temperature in body.

questions.text: An aged woman around 65 has vascular injury in the inferior frontal gyrus. Which of the following systems given  below would be affected the most?
questions.solution:
The premotor area is located just anterior to the motor area, occupying parts of the superior, middle, and inferior frontal gyri. Areas 6 and 8 of Brodmann, and Areas 44 and 45 (the motor speech area of Broca) are part of the premotor area and are important for motor control and the execution of voluntary movement. Additionally, the frontal eye field - an area of the cortex involved in controlling eye movement - is also closely related to the premotor area.

questions.text: In a motor bike accident, a boy was injured, CT brain shows the same lesion in posterior end of superior temporal gyrus. What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Wernicke's aphasia is a type of language deficit that is characterized by impaired comprehension of spoken and written words and sentences and difficulty producing language, hence it causes fluent aphasia. It is caused by a lesion in the posterior part of the language network, commonly a vascular embolism to the inferior division of the middle cerebral artery.

 

Broca's aphasia is a type of language deficit characterized by difficulty in producing language. It is caused by a lesion in the inferior frontal convolution or surrounding anterior perisylvian and insular cortex, largely due to occlusion of the superior division of the MCA. Speech is nonfluent, labored, and interrupted by many word-finding pauses.

 

Conduction aphasia is a type of language deficit characterized by fluent but inaccurate language output with phonemic paraphasias, extreme difficulty in repetition, impaired naming, and impaired reading of words aloud. It is caused by a lesion in the temporoparietal or dorsal perisylvian region that interrupts the phonological loop connecting the Broca's area and the Wernicke's area.



 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 533
Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th Edition Page no. 611

questions.text: Which of the following trigeminal nerve nuclei receives pain and temperature perception from the face?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Spinal nucleus
 
  • The trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V) is responsible for sensory perception from the face, including pain and temperature.
  • There are three main nuclei associated with the trigeminal nerve:
  1. Main sensory nucleus (or principal sensory nucleus): This nucleus receives fine touch, pressure, and proprioceptive sensory information from the face.
  2. Spinal nucleus (or spinal trigeminal nucleus): This nucleus receives pain and temperature sensory information from the face.
  3. Mesencephalic nucleus: This nucleus is involved in proprioception and receives sensory information related to jaw movement and muscle stretch.

questions.text: In the case of a pontine lesion affecting the right medial lemniscus, which of the following sensations will be affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Left sided tactile sensations
 
  • A pontine lesion affecting the right medial lemniscus will result in the impairment of sensory information from the left side of the body.
  • The medial lemniscus decussates (crosses over) in the medulla. This means that the right medial lemniscus carries sensory information from the left side of the body, and the left medial lemniscus carries sensory information from the right side of the body.
  • The person will experience a loss of tactile sensations (fine touch, vibration, and proprioception) on the left side of their body due to the disruption in the transmission of sensory signals through the right medial lemniscus.
 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page No 387,388,389

  • The petrotympanic fissure is a narrow opening located between the petrous part of the temporal bone and the tympanic part of the temporal bone.
  • After exiting through the petrotympanic fissure, the chorda tympani enters the middle ear cavity.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the spinal cord is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Central canal lies in the white matter
 
  • The central canal of the spinal cord is a small, fluid-filled channel that runs through the center of the spinal cord.
  • The central canal is surrounded by gray matter, not white matter.
  • The gray matter contains neuronal cell bodies and is butterfly-shaped in cross-section, while the white matter contains nerve fibers and is located externally to the gray matter.
  • he central canal of the spinal cord is a cerebrospinal fluid-filled channel that runs the length of the spinal cord.
  • It is located in the center of the gray matter, which is surrounded by the white matter.
  • The gray matter of the spinal cord is divided into dorsal, ventral, and lateral horns.
  • The spinal cord is suspended in the subarachnoid space by a series of denticulate ligaments, which are extensions of the pia mater that anchor the spinal cord to the dura mater.
  • These ligaments help to protect the spinal cord from injury and provide support for its weight.
 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page No 856-860

choices.text: Postganglionic Sympathetic fibers from superior cervical ganglion
Postganglionic Sympathetic fibers in the frontotemporal branch of CN V

questions.text: What fibers supplies Dilator pupillae iridis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Postganglionic Sympathetic fibers from superior cervical ganglion
 
  • The dilator pupillae muscle is responsible for dilating the pupil of the eye (mydriasis).
  • The sympathetic nervous system controls the dilation of the pupil, and the postganglionic sympathetic fibers that supply the dilator pupillae muscle originate from the superior cervical ganglion.
  • These fibers travel along the internal carotid artery and reach the dilator pupillae muscle, causing its contraction and pupil dilation.
  • The sympathetic nervous system is responsible for the dilation of the pupil, while the parasympathetic nervous system is responsible for constriction.
  • The superior cervical ganglion is a sympathetic ganglion located in the neck, which sends postganglionic fibers to the dilator pupillae muscle. When these fibers are stimulated, they cause the muscle to contract, resulting in dilation of the pupil.
  • Option 1 is incorrect because the Edinger-Westphal Nucleus supplies the sphincter pupillae muscle, which is responsible for constriction of the pupil.
  • Option 2 is incorrect because the Ciliary Ganglion supplies the sphincter pupillae muscle and the ciliary muscle, which is responsible for accommodation of the lens.
  • Option 4 is incorrect because the frontotemporal branch of CN V (Trigeminal Nerve) supplies the skin of the forehead, temple, and scalp, and does not have any role in the innervation of the iris muscles.
 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1464.e46

questions.text:
The molecular layer of cerebellum is made of? 
(i) Single row of Purkinje cells 
(ii) Stellate cells 
(iii) Basket cells 
(iv) Granular cells
questions.solution:
The molecular layer of the cerebellum primarily contains:

  • Stellate cells
  • Basket cells

These are the inhibitory interneurons that make connections in the molecular layer. The Purkinje cells are located in the Purkinje cell layer, not the molecular layer, and the granular cells are found in the granular layer, which is deeper.



Reference: Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st edition, Page no 335, 336

questions.text: Hemiballismus is caused by lesion in which part of brain?
questions.solution:
• Wild, uncontrolled movements of one arm or one leg are signs of hemiballismus. The limbs move in an unwanted, ballistic, and failing manner. It is caused due to lesion in sub thalamic nucleus.
 
  • Hemiballismus is a hyperkinetic movement disorder characterized by sudden, violent, and involuntary flinging movements, typically involving one side of the body (contralateral to the brain lesion).
 
  • It is most commonly caused by a lesion in the subthalamic nucleus of the basal ganglia, often due to a stroke.
  • The subthalamic nucleus plays a critical role in the indirect pathway of the basal ganglia, which helps suppress unwanted movements.
  • Damage to this structure results in disinhibition of motor activity, leading to the uncontrollable movements seen in hemiballismus.


Reference: Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st edition, Page no 367-370.

questions.text: The mesencephalic nucleus of trigeminal nerve receives which of the following sensations
questions.solution:
• The trigeminal nerve has three branches the ophthalmic (V1), maxillary (V2), and mandibular (V3) divisions.
  • The first-order neurons for each division originate from trigeminal ganglion also known as gasserion ganglion.
  • These first-order neurons carry sensory information from the face to the brainstem. Upon entering the brainstem, the fibers synapse with second-order neurons in specific nuclei:
1. Principal Sensory Nucleus (Main Sensory Nucleus):
-Receives input from all three divisions of the trigeminal nerve and is Located in the pons.
-Second-order neurons here carry discriminative touch and proprioceptive information.
2. Spinal Trigeminal Nucleus (Spinal Nucleus of Trigeminal):
-Receives input mainly from the maxillary and mandibular divisions.
-It is Located in the medulla.
-Second-order neurons here carry pain and temperature sensations. Other trigeminal nerve nuclei

1. Mesenephalic nucleus of trigeminal nerve -located in the brainstem, near the periaqueductal gray and lateral to the cerebral aqueduct.
- It is the only structure in the central nervous system to contain the cell bodies of first-order sensory neurons. Neurons in this nucleus are pseudounipolar and receive proprioceptive afferent information from the mandible.
- They send efferent projections to the trigeminal motor nucleus to mediate monosynaptic jaw jerk reflexes.

2. Motor nucleus of trigeminal nerve
The Trigeminal Motor Nucleus refers to a region located in the dorsolateral pontine tegmentum that is responsible for controlling the muscles involved in jaw movement. It differs from other motor nuclei in that it receives inhibitory input from mechanoreceptors and free nerve endings, which compensates for its unique organization. This nucleus plays a crucial role in speech control, mastication, and can contribute to masticatory myofascial pains.

Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice,42nd Edition, Page No 453-454.

The terminal branches emerge from the parotid gland and diverge to supply the various facial muscles as follows :

questions.solution:
From medial to lateral, the afferent columns in the floor of the fourth ventricle are general visceral, special visceral, general somatic, special somatic.

Embryologically, the continuous addition of neuroblasts to the mantle layer of the neural tube produces thickenings ventrally and dorsally – producing the basal and alar plates respectively. A longitudinal groove, called sulcus limitans, marks the boundary between the two.

Basal Plate:
  • Ventral thickening
  • Give rise to motor nucleigeneral visceral efferent nuclei, special visceral efferent of CN IX, X, and XII; and somatic efferent of XII
  • Forms the motor part of the spinal cord (ventral horns)

Alar plate:
  • Dorsal thickenings
  • Give rise to sensory nuclei CN V, VII, VIII, IX, X, inferior olivary nucleus, and mesencephalic nucleus of CNV
  • Forms the sensory part of the spinal cord (dorsal horns).
  • The rhombic lip develops into the cerebellum and its nuclei


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st edition, Page no 253.

questions.text: Which of the following vessels is involved in the condition affecting the region marked in red in the image shown below?
questions.solution:
The image provided is indicative of lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome, which can occur due to a stroke affecting the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA).

The clinical manifestations correspond to the affected neuroanatomical structures in the lateral medulla:

•Descending tract and nucleus of CN V (trigeminal nerve): Loss of pain and sensation on the ipsilateral side of the face.

•Inferior cerebellar peduncle:Ipsilateral ataxia affecting gait and limbs.


•Lateral spinothalamic tract: Loss of pain and temperature sensation on the contralateral side of the body.

•Cranial nerves IX and X: Ipsilateral paralysis of the palate and vocal cord, along with a diminished gag reflex, leading to dysphagia and dysarthria.


•Vestibular nucleus: Nystagmus, diplopia, vertigo, and nausea.

•Descending sympathetic tract: Ipsilateral Horner‘s syndrome, characterized by miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis.



 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st edition, Page no 285,315 .
