questions.text: At what level does the spinal cord end in infants?
questions.solution:
In infants, the spinal cord ends with L3.

As the child grows, the spinal cord moves with age. Thus, in adults, the distal end of the spinal cord is located at the inferior border of L1.

The nerve roots from the inferior end of the spinal cord form the cauda equina and exit through the intervertebral foramina. These fibers tend to swim in a sustainable bag and start when the needle moves like vertebral anesthesia.

Thus, to minimize the possibility of damage to the spinal cord, a vertebral anesthesia is administered to an adult under the lower boundary L1 and a child under the lower boundary L3.

Remember, 

Age-wise termination of spinal cord 

  • Fetus (3rd month) → extends entire length of vertebral canal

  • Newborn / Infant → up to L3 (sometimes L4)

  • Child (around 1 year) → around L2–L3

  • Adult → up to L1–L2

 That’s why lumbar puncture is done:

  • At L4–L5 in infants (to stay below cord)

  • At L3–L4 or L4–L5 in adults.



Reference: Millers Anesthesia 9th edition page no 1414

questions.text: Which of the following stages of meiosis has oogonia at the time of birth?

Meiosis 1 of oogenesis begins in the embryonic period itself, but is arrested in the diplotene stage of prophase I, which gets completed at the time of puberty.

2. Primary Oocyte- Halted in diplotene stage of prophase 1 until puberty. It is diploid.

questions.text: At what stage of spermatocyte maturation does independent assortment of maternal and paternal chromosomes take place?
questions.solution:
When the primary spermatocyte (2n) transforms into two secondary spermatocytes (1n) during meiosis I in spermatogenesis, independent assortment takes place.

Meiosis I separates homologous chromosomes after crossing over ( which is responsible for exchange of genetic material ) and reduces the cell from diploid to haploid. 

Meiosis II separates the sister chromatids present in the chromosome which contain replicated DNA.

questions.text: Which of the following is not derived from ectoderm?
questions.solution:
1. All are derived from ectoderm except Arrector pili is a smooth muscle in the dermis, derived from lateral plate mesoderm.The skin has two layers which develop from different parts of the embryo. questions.text: Which of the following muscles is not a mesoderm derivative?
questions.solution:
The muscular system is made up of skeletal, smooth, and cardiac muscle, with the exception of a few types of smooth muscle tissue which are derived from the ectoderm. Certain types of smooth muscle - pupillary, mammary gland, and sweat gland muscles - derive from ectoderm (i.e., sphincter and dilator pupillae, myoepithelial cells). Skeletal muscle originates from the paraxial mesoderm which forms somites from the occipital to the sacral regions and somitomeres in the head. As precursor cells, known as myoblasts, fuse and form long, multinucleated muscle fibers, myofibrils soon appear in the cytoplasm, and by the end of the third month, cross striations can be observed. Tendons which attach muscles to bones stem from the sclerotome components of these somites. Smooth muscle arises from the splanchnic layer of the lateral plate mesoderm surrounding the gut, while cardiac muscle is formed from the splanchnic layer of lateral plate mesoderm surrounding the heart tube

 

Reference: Langman' Medical Embryology Edition 14 th page no 163,164

questions.text: What is the source of the buccopharyngeal membrane?

questions.text: From where are the branchial arch nerves derived?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Neural crest The branchial arch nerves are derived from the neural crest, which is a group of cells that form during embryonic development. The neural crest cells migrate to different parts of the body, where they differentiate into a variety of tissues, including the branchial arch nerve. The branchial arch nerves, such as the trigeminal nerve (CN V), facial nerve (CN VII), glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), and vagus nerve (CN X), are derived from the neural crest cells that populate the respective branchial arches.

 

Reference: Langman' Medical Embryology Edition 14 th page no 286

questions.text: Where does the ureteric bud grow from?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Mesonephros The ureteric bud (metanephric diverticulum) is an outgrowth from the mesonephric duct, which is derived from the mesonephros. The mesonephros is an intermediate stage in kidney development and serves as a temporary functional kidney during early embryonic development. The ureteric bud arises from the mesonephros and plays a crucial role in the development of the permanent kidney, or metanephros.

 

Reference: Langman' Medical Embryology Edition 14 th page no 257

questions.text: Which of the following structures is formed by the dorsal mesentery?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Greater omentum
  • The structure formed by the dorsal mesentery is the Greater omentum.
  • The dorsal mesentery is a double layer of peritoneum that extends from the posterior abdominal wall and connects to various abdominal organs during embryonic development.
  • The Greater omentum is a part of the dorsal mesentery and is formed by its two layers.
  • It is a large, apron-like fold of peritoneum that hangs down from the greater curvature of the stomach, covering the small intestines.
  • The Greater omentum plays a role in protecting and insulating the abdominal organs and may also assist in limiting the spread of infection within the abdominal cavity.
 


 

Reference: Langman' Medical Embryology Edition 14 th page no 232,233

questions.text: Chordoma arises from which of the following options given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Notochord
 
  • Chordoma is a rare type of cancer.
  • It arises from remnants of the notochord, an embryonic structure present during early development.
  • The notochord is a flexible, rod-like structure that forms along the central axis of the developing embryo.
  • During normal development, the notochord is replaced by the vertebral column (spine) in most parts of the body.
  • However, small remnants of the notochord can persist at certain sites, particularly in the region of the base of the skull and the sacrococcygeal area (near the tailbone).
  • Chordoma occurs when these remnants of the notochord give rise to abnormal growths or tumors.
  • These tumors most commonly occur in the skull base or the sacrum (the triangular bone at the base of the spine)
 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 567

questions.text: The reason for the long left recurrent laryngeal N. is due to the persistence of which arch artery
Pick the remnant of Wolffian duct in a female.
questions.solution:
The mesonephric duct is an embryonic structure that develops during fetal growth and eventually disappears in both sexes. In some people, however, part of it may persist as a structure known as a Gartner duct cyst. These cysts can be found between the layers of the broad ligament along the lateral wall of the uterus and in the wall of the vagina. They are typically filled with fluid and can range in size from a few millimeters to several centimeters. They do not usually cause any symptoms, however they can be painful if they become large enough to press against other structures.




 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 353

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a child with evisceration of bowel loops coming out of a defect in the abdominal wall right to the umbilicus
questions.solution:
Gastroschisis is a birth defect that results in the intestines and sometimes other organs, such as the stomach, liver, and spleen, protruding outside the baby's body. It is a congenital defect that usually occurs in the abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus. In many cases, the abdominal wall may not fully form, leaving a hole or an “omphalocele.” The cause of gastroschisis is unknown. Most fetuses with gastroschisis have normal intelligence, growth, and development. Noted symptoms for gastroschisis include the protrusion of the baby’s internal organs from the body, abdominal wall defects (omphalocele), umbilical hernia, and small bowel/intestine prolapse. Babies with gastroschisis commonly have bowel obstruction and can also have other systemic defects such as cardiac and genitourinary anomalies. Treatment includes physical therapy and, if necessary, surgical correction.



 

Reference: Langman' Medical Embryology Edition 14 th page no 382,383,401

questions.text: A young patient with hypoparathyroidism and tetany arrived with a missing thymus. In this situation, which of the following marked areas in the image is defective
questions.solution:
DiGeorge syndrome is caused by a defect in the third pharyngeal pouch, which has the thymus and the inferior parathyroid gland as its derivatives. The thymus and parathyroid glands in the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches fail to differentiate. caused by the loss of chromosome 22's long arm. Consequently, it is also known as 22q deletion syndrome.

questions.text: From where is the marked structure derived ?
questions.solution:
The marked structure in the provided specimen is membranous part of the interventricular spectrum, which is generated from the endocardial cushion.

DEVELOPMENT OF INTERVENTRICULAR SEPTUM

The muscular interventricular (IV) septum which has developed from the floor of the primitive atrium in the midline grows toward the fused AV cushions.
Until 7th week, there is the presence of a crescent-shaped interventricular foramen
between the free edge of the interventricular septum and the fused endocardial cushions.
The membranous IV septum closes the IV foramen.
This happens by the end of 7th week due to the fusion of bulbar ridges and the endocardial cushion.
The right bulbar ridge, the left bulbar ridge and the endocardial cushion
fuse to form membranous part of interventricular septum.
The membranous part of the interventricular septum is derived from an extension of tissue from the right side of the endocardial cushion to the muscular part of the septum as well as neural crest cells.

 

 

Reference: Langman' Medical Embryology Edition 14 th page no 194,197,199,200

questions.text: Saccules is developed from which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
The inner structures of the ear, such as the cochlea, the vestibular apparatus, and the acoustic nerve, develop from the surface ectoderm. This happens in two phases: the formation of the otic placode and the subsequent development of the otic vesicle from this ectodermal region. The otic placode is formed during embryonic development, when the ectoderm thickens along the boundaries of the first and second pharyngeal arches. This then develops into the otic vesicle, and continues to develop and differentiate into the structures of the inner ear.

 

The saccule develops from the pars inferior of the utricle, a structure which develops from the saccule. The pars inferior, located at the base of the utricle, is a thin layer of squamous epithelial cells. During development, these cells are replaced by columnar epithelial cells which form the saccule. The saccule then contributes to the development of the cochlea and the auditory tube. The saccule is innervated by the nerve fibers from the vestibular portion of the vestibulocochlear nerve. Additionally, the saccule plays a role in controlling balance and maintaining equilibrium.



Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 269

questions.text: The fetal circulation is different from adult circulation. It recieves oxygenated blood from palcenta via X and deoxygenated blood goes back through:
questions.solution:
In fetal circulation, oxygenated blood is received from the placenta via the umbilical vein (option 2). Deoxygenated blood is returned to the placenta through the umbilical arteries (option 1).

Explanation:

  • Umbilical vein: Carries oxygen-rich blood from the placenta to the fetus.

  • Umbilical arteries: Carry deoxygenated blood from the fetus back to the placenta for oxygenation.

  • Ductus venosus: Bypasses the liver, allowing oxygenated blood to reach the heart more efficiently.

  • Ductus arteriosus: Connects the pulmonary artery to the aorta, bypassing the lungs since they are not yet functional.

Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no228

Option D :  The muscles of the larynx, including the intrinsic muscles that control vocal cord movement, are derived from the sixth and fourth pharyngeal arches.


Reference: Langman’ Medical Embryology Edition 14 th page no 285

questions.text: Identify which of the following is not a derivative of mesonephric tubules/duct.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Appendix of testis.
  • Appendix of Testis → Derived from the paramesonephric (Müllerian) duct, not the mesonephric tubules.
  • Gartner's Duct, Trigone of Bladder, Epoophoron & Paroophoron → All derived from mesonephric (Wolffian) structures.



Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1296.e1,353

questions.text: What is a remnant of the Hydatid of Morgagni?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Paramesonephric Duct
 
  • The remnant of the Hydatid of Morgagni is the appendix of the paramesonephric duct, also known as the appendix of the ovary.
  • The paramesonephric duct (Mullerian duct) is an embryonic duct found in the female reproductive system.
  • In females, the mesonephric duct degenerates and disappears, while the paramesonephric duct gives rise to the fallopian tubes, uterus, and upper part of the vagina.




Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 353

questions.text: Where does the thyroid cartilage grow from?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: 4th Branchial Arch
 
  • The thyroid cartilage arises from the fourth branchial arch during embryonic development.
  • The fourth branchial arch gives rise to various structures in the head and neck region, including the upper part of the hyoid bone, the lesser horn of the hyoid bone, and the anterior aspect of the thyroid cartilage.





 
Reference: Langman’ Medical Embryology Edition 14 th page no 285

questions.text: Which arch of the aorta gives rise to the maxillary artery?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: First
 
  • The maxillary artery is a branch of the external carotid artery, which, in turn, is a direct branch of the common carotid artery.
  • The common carotid artery on the right side arises directly from the brachiocephalic trunk (innominate artery), which is the first branch of the aortic arch.




Reference: Langman’ Medical Embryology Edition 14 th page no 285

questions.text: What is derived from Meckel's diverticulum?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: vitellointestinal duct
 
  • Meckel's diverticulum is a remnant of the omphalomesenteric (vitelline) duct, which connects the midgut of the developing embryo to the yolk sac during early development.
  • As the intestines elongate and rotate during fetal development, the omphalomesenteric duct normally degenerates and disappears.
  • In some cases, however, the duct fails to regress completely, leading to the persistence of Meckel's diverticulum, which is a small outpouching from the ileum (part of the small intestine).
Rule of 2 in Meckel's diverticulum:- 
  • 2% population
  • 2 inches in length
  • 2 feet from ileo-caecal valve
  • 2 types of mucosa- gastric or pancreatic



Reference: Langman’ Medical Embryology Edition 14 th page no 249

questions.text: What is the origin of the cornea's stroma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Neural crest cells  
 
  • The cornea is made up of three layers: the epithelium, the stroma, and the endothelium.





Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 204,266

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is not derived from the pharyngeal arch?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Levator Palpebrae superioris
 
  • The levator palpebrae superioris is a muscle responsible for elevating the upper eyelid.
  • It is not derived from the pharyngeal arches. Instead, it is derived from the mesoderm of the mesencephalic neural crest.
  • The other muscles listed in the options are indeed derived from the pharyngeal arches:
A. Tensor Tympani : Derived from the first pharyngeal arch.
C. Palatine Tensor : Derived from the third pharyngeal arch.
D. Orbicularis oculi : Derived from the mesoderm of the second pharyngeal arch.

Trick:- 
For any muscle consider the nerve supply. LPS is supplied by 3rd nerve, it is not a nerve of pharyngeal arch hence LPS is not a pharyngeal arch muscle.




Reference: Langman’ Medical Embryology Edition 14 th page no 285

questions.text: Which of the following is not derived from the pharyngeal arch?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Palatine Tonsils
 
  • The palatine tonsils are not derived from the pharyngeal arches.
  • They are derived from the endoderm of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches.
  • The other structures listed, the tensor tympani, the tensor veli palatini, and the mylohyoid, are all derived from the first pharyngeal arch




Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 276

questions.text: Which of the following is a remnant of the mesonephric (Wolffian) duct in females?
questions.solution:
The mesonephric (Wolffian) duct primarily regresses in females but leaves behind vestigial structures, including:

  • Gartner’s duct – Found along the lateral walls of the vagina and uterus, sometimes forming cysts.
  • Epoophoron – Located near the ovary and fallopian tube.
  • Paroophoron – Small remnants near the epoophoron.

Other options

  • The Müllerian duct (option 2) develops into the female reproductive tract (uterus, fallopian tubes, and upper vagina), not a remnant of the mesonephric duct.
  • Bartholin’s gland (option 3) originates from the urogenital sinus.
  • Round ligament (option 4) arises from the gubernaculum, not the mesonephric duct.
Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 343

questions.text: Ligamentum teres is remnant of :
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Umbilical Vein
 
  • The remnant of the Umbilical Vein is the ligamentum teres (round ligament of the liver).
  • During fetal development, the umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetal liver.
  • Some of this blood bypasses the liver through the ductus venosus and flows directly to the inferior vena cava.
  • After birth, the placental circulation ceases, and the umbilical vein is no longer needed.
  • The umbilical vein undergoes degeneration and becomes a fibrous cord known as the ligamentum teres.




Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 230

questions.text: Which of the following is not derived from the first pharyngeal arch?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Stapes
 
  • The first pharyngeal arch, also known as the mandibular arch, contributes to the development of various structures in the head and neck region during embryonic development.
  • Malleus, incus, Mandible  are derived from the first pharyngeal arch:
  • However, the Stapes (stirrup bone), which is the third and innermost of the three tiny bones in the middle ear, is not derived from the first pharyngeal arch. It is derived from 2nd pharyngeal arch except the foot plate.




Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 270,277,278

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with a rokitansky protuberance?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Teratoma
 
  • A Rokitansky nodule, also known as a dermoid plug, is a solid protuberance that projects from an ovarian cyst in the context of a mature cystic teratoma.
  • It often contains calcific, dental, adipose, hair, and/or sebaceous components.
  • Teratomas are a type of germ cell tumor that can contain a variety of tissues, including hair, teeth, and bone. They are the most common type of ovarian tumor in children and young women.
  • Dysgerminomas, yolk sac tumors, and sex cord-stromal tumors are all types of germ cell tumors, but they do not typically contain a Rokitansky nodule.




Reference:https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5359144/

questions.text: From where does the lens of the eye develop?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Surface ectoderm 
 
  • The lens placode, a thickening of the surface ectoderm, forms on the surface of the developing optic cup.
  • The lens placode invaginates and separates from the surface ectoderm to form the lens vesicle.
  • The lens vesicle then differentiates to form the lens of the eye.


Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 204

questions.text: A child presented to the casualty with tetanic spasms and hypocalcemia. The mother complains of repeated hospitalizations with recurrent infections. On X-ray the thymic shadow was absent. Anomaly to which of the following structure given below is the cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
• The clinical presentation of the child with hypocalcemia, recurrent infections, and absent thymic shadow on X-ray is consistent with DiGeorge Syndrome. It occurs due to chromosome 22q11.2 deletion.
  • In this condition, there is a developmental anomaly in the formation of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches, which give rise to the thymus and parathyroid glands. As a result, there is aplasia or hypoplasia of the thymus and parathyroid glands, leading to immunodeficiency(T cell defect and defective cellular immunity) and hypocalcemia, respectively.
  • Third and fourth pharyngeal pouches - depicted by 'C' in the image.
        
Reference: Langman’s Medical Embryology 14 edition page no 290,291 .

questions.text: The following marked structure will develop into?
questions.solution:
Answer: (1). Median umbilical ligament

The structure marked ‘A’ in the given diagram of a developing embryo represents the allantois.
The median umbilical ligament is a remnant of the fetal urachus and the urachus is a fibrous remnant of the allantois. 

 

Option (B) Medial umbilical ligament is a remnant of obliterated fetal umbilical arteries

(Option C) The ligamentum teres hepatis (round ligament of the liver) represents the obliterated left umbilical vein. 

(Option D) The falciform ligament is a sickle-shaped, broad, and thin fold of peritoneum that attaches the liver to the front body wall and divides the liver into the left lobe and right lobe.

Reference: Langman’s Medical Embryology, 14th Edition, Page. No- 182, 249.

questions.text:
Which aortic arch defect is responsible for the given defect?


 
1. 4th Left
2. 4th Right
3. 6th Right
4. 6th Left
questions.solution:
Answer: (4). 6th Left

The given image shows a patent ductus arteriosus. This is an acyanotic congenital heart defect, involving a patent left-to-right shunt between the pulmonary artery and the aorta, as shown in the figure below.

 

After birth, the ductus arteriosus undergoes active constriction and eventual obliteration. A patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) occurs when the DA fails to completely close postnatally. The DA is thought to be derived from the distal part of the embryonic left sixth aortic arch.

(Option A, B) Fourth aortic arch - The right arch contributes to the right proximal subclavian artery. The left arch gives rise to the medial portion of the aortic arch.

(Option C) Sixth aortic arch - The right and left arches separate into ventral and dorsal segments. The ventral segments are responsible for the formation of the pulmonary arteries bilaterally. The left ventral arch also contributes to the formation of the pulmonary trunk. The right dorsal arch regresses. The left dorsal arch forms the ductus arteriosus, which later closes and is termed the ligamentum arteriosum.



Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21th Edition, Page. No- 940

questions.text: Identify the given anomaly?
questions.solution:
Image shows Sacrococcygeal teratoma which occurs due to persistence of pluripotent cells of primitive streak in Sacrococcygeal region.
It contains tissues from all three germ layers includes skin ,hair ,cartilage and bone.
They are usually benign in nature. They occur due to defective migration of cells.

Reference: Langman’s Medical Embryology, 14th Edition, Page. No- 64-65.

questions.text: The following condition seen in the image results from failure of fusion of:
questions.solution:
Cleft lip is a congenital deformity that occurs due to the failure of fusion between the medial nasal prominence and the maxillary prominence during embryonic development. This can result in various facial anomalies:

Types and Causes of Clefts:
1. Cleft Lip:
Caused by the failure of fusion between the maxillary prominence and medial nasal prominence.
It can be unilateral or bilateral.
Severity ranges from a small notch in the upper lip to a double cleft extending into both nostrils.
Often associated with underdevelopment of the maxilla, affecting the incisors' region.
2. Median (Midline) Cleft Lip:
A rare condition due to the failure of fusion of the two medial nasal prominences in the midline.
3. Oblique Facial Cleft:
Occurs due to the failure of the maxillary prominence to fuse with the lateral nasal prominence along the nasolacrimal groove.
In this case, the nasolacrimal duct may be exposed externally.
These developmental anomalies arise during the early weeks of gestation, impacting facial structure and function.

questions.text: During surgery for patent ductus arteriosus, which anatomical structure is most susceptible to injury?
questions.solution:
Aortic arches Arterial structures
First aortic arch Part of maxillary arteries bilaterally
Second aortic arch Stapedial and hyoid arteries bilaterally
Third aortic arch Common carotid arteries and proximal portion of internal carotid arteries bilaterally
Forth aortic arch Right: Proximal portion of the right subclavian artery
Left: aortic arch
Fifth aortic arch Regress completely
Sixth aortic arch Right: proximal right pulmonary artery
Left: proximal left pulmonary artery, ductus arteriosus

The patent ductus arterious is due to a defect in the 6th aortic arch. On the right side, this arch forms the right pulmonary artery proximally and disappears distally. On the left side, the distal part remains patent to form the ductus arteriosus that shunts blood from the right ventricle to the dorsal aorta. This is obliterated after birth forming the ligamentum arteriosum. If the ductus arteriosus remains patent after birth, it is referred to as patent ductus arteriosus. As the left recurrent laryngeal nerve loops under the 6th arch artery it is more prone for injury during surgery for PDA.
Ref: Inderbir Singh's Human Embryology - 11th Edition • Page no :244 - 245

choices.text: Failure in closure of posterior neuropore of neural tube
Failure in closure of anterior neuropore of neural tube
Failure in closure of complete neural tube
Failure in closure of caudal neuropore of neural tube

questions.text: What is the embryological basis of the developmental defect shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image shows anencephaly.

  • Anencephaly is a severe neural tube defect where there is absence of a major portion of the brain, skull, and scalp, especially the forebrain and cranial vault.

  • It results from failure of the anterior (rostral) neuropore to close during embryogenesis.

  • The anterior neuropore normally closes around day 25 of development.

  • This defect leads to exposure of the developing brain to amniotic fluid, resulting in degeneration.


A condition in which the anterior end of the neural tube (cranial end) does not close is called exencephaly. As a result, the cranial vault does not form, leaving the deformed brain exposed. The exposed brain tissue degenerates, leaving behind a mass of necrotic tissue. This defect, characterized by the absence of large parts of the brain, skull, and scalp, is known as anencephaly. The brain stem remains intact.

In some cases, neural tube closure defects may extend caudally, affecting the spinal cord. This is known as Craniorachisis, which has a great flaw in the brain involvement and the spine.

Stages of Neurogenesis

The notochord thickens the overlying ectoderm to form the neural plate. The neural plate elongates and the lateral edges are raised to form the neural folds and the medial region is lowered to form the neural groove.

The neural folds approach and fuse along the midline in a craniocaudal direction to form a tubular structure called the neural tube. The anterior opening of the neural tube (cranial neuropore) closes on the 25th day, and the posterior opening (caudal neuropore) closes on the 28th day.

The neural tube becomes the central nervous system.

Reference:Langmans medical embryology 14th edition page no 332

questions.text: A newborn presented to the NICU with respiratory distress and meconium discharge from the umbilicus. The condition occurs due to the patency of the which structure?
questions.solution:
The newborn has meconium discharge from the umbilicus, which is a classic sign of a patent vitellointestinal duct (also called the omphalomesenteric duct or yolk stalk).

  • This duct normally connects the midgut to the yolk sac in early development and obliterates by the 7th week of gestation.

  • If it remains patent, intestinal contents (including meconium) can discharge through the umbilicus.

  • Respiratory distress can also occur due to associated anomalies or complications like sepsis or aspiration.


The vitellointestinal duct is a thin conduit that resembles a stalk that connects the primitive gut to the final yolk sac. It is sometimes referred to as the omphalomesenteric duct, yolk stalk, or vitelline duct.
The embryo becomes completely encased in ectoderm as a result of folding in the lateral and cephalocaudal orientations, with the exception of the area where the vitellointestinal duct passes. There is a circular entrance in this area that is now known as the umbilical opening.
By the seventh week of development, the vitellointestinal duct has entirely formed.

Other options: 
 

1. Mesonephric duct: Develops into parts of the male reproductive system (e.g., vas deferens), not connected to the umbilicus.

3. Urachus: A persistent urachus connects the bladder to the umbilicus and would lead to urine discharge, not meconium.

4. Allantois: It forms the urachus, so a persistent allantois would also cause urinary discharge, not meconium.



Reference: Langmans medical embryology 14th edition Page no 104,249

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the diagram showing the development of ovarian follicles.
questions.solution:
The structures marked in the image are secondary follicles, also called antral follicles.

Follicle Development:

At birth, the ovarian cortex contains numerous primordial follicles, each of which contains a primary oocyte surrounded by a single layer of squamous follicular cells. Most of these follicles degenerate in prepubertal age and are called atretic follicles. During puberty, about 20 primordial follicles are activated each menstrual cycle. Of these 20 primordial follicles, only one follicle is dominant, which reaches maturity and releases the oocyte during ovulation.
 

  • Primordial follicle → Primary oocyte + single layer of flat granulosa cells (resting pool).

  • Primary follicle → Granulosa cells become cuboidal; zona pellucida begins to form.

  • Secondary (preantral) follicle → Multiple granulosa layers, theca cells differentiate.

  • Tertiary (antral) follicle → Fluid-filled antrum appears; FSH-dependent growth.

  • Graafian (mature) follicle → Large antrum, cumulus oophorus; ruptures at ovulation.





Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice 41st edition page no 1304-1305

questions.text: Which of the following has dense irregular connective tissue?
questions.solution:
The dermis of the skin, the walls of large tubular organs like the alimentary canal, in glandular tissue, and organ capsules are all examples of dense irregular connective tissue.

Highly fibrous tissues with regularly oriented fires, such as fasciae and apo- neuroses, or bigger bundles like ligaments or tendons, are considered regular connective tissues.

questions.text: Which cells on the given slide are holocrine?

Structures marked in the diagram:
A: Sweat gland: Merocrine glands
B: Sweat gland ducts
C: Sebaceous glands: Holocrine glands
D: Root of the hair follicle

The pilosebaceous unit, which also includes the hair follicle and the arrector pili muscle, is made up of sebaceous glands which are small saccular structures located in the dermis. They cover the whole body, with the exception of the thick, hairless skin of the palm, soles, and flexor surfaces of the fingers.

questions.text: Which one of the following junctional complexes are not present in the arrow marked part on the slide?

questions.text: Which of the following layers has a large number of desmosomes?
questions.solution:
The given histopathology image is of skin.
Stratum spinosum or prickle cell layer contains abundant desmosomes marked with the legend 'C' in the image.

Picture shows following layers of epidermis:
A : Stratum corneum
B : Stratum granulosum
C : Stratum spinosum
D : Stratum basale

The stratum spinosum, also known as the prickle cell layer, is made up of several layers of densely packed keratinocytes that interdigitate with one another via a large number of cell surface projections. Desmosomes, which give the layer its tensile strength and cohesiveness, anchor the cells to one another. As additional cells are created in the basal layer, these suprabasal cells, which are dedicated to terminal differentiation, eventually ascend upward towards the cornified layer.

In pemphigus group of disorder antibodies are formed against desmosomes, that lead to destruction of cell to cell adhesion and formation of blisters in skin.



Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 145,146,147,148

questions.text: Where are Meissner's corpuscles located?

questions.text: Where does the peripheral processes of spiral ganglion end?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: C
The peripheral processes of the spiral ganglion end in the organ of Corti, which is a sensory organ located in the cochlea. The organ of Corti contains hair cells, which are the sensory cells that respond to sound. The peripheral processes of the spiral ganglion synapse with the hair cells, and this is how the auditory nerve transmits sound information to the brain.
Other options :

questions.text: What speech impairment results from damage to the area of the brain shown in the micrograph below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Sensory aphasia
 
  • Sensory aphasia (Wernicke's aphasia) is a type of aphasia that results from damage to the temporal lobe of the brain.
  • Damage to this area of the brain can disrupt the ability to understand language, both spoken and written.
  • People with sensory aphasia may have difficulty comprehending what others are saying, and they may also have difficulty finding the right words to express themselves.
  • The micrograph shows the temporal lobe of the brain, and the area that is damaged is Wernicke's area.

questions.text: Which tissue is represented by the following hematoxylin and eosin-stained biopsy?
questions.solution:
Tonsils are small mass of lymphatic tissue located in the wall of the pharynx at the rear of the throat of humans. The term is most commonly used to describe palatine tonsils.

Microscopically, the tonsil is a mass of lymphoid follicles supported on a connective tissue framework. In addition, the center of each of these nodules is densely packed with lymphocytes, and is referred to as the germinal center. 

The luminal surfaces of the tonsils are coated in non-keratinizing stratified squamous epithelium.

questions.text: Locate the structure given.
questions.solution:
The arrow points toawrds Purkinje Cells. (characterized by its flask shaped structurebranching dendrites seen) The histology of the grey matter of the cerebellum consists of an outer molecular layer, a middle Purkinje layer, and an inner granule cell layer. The molecular layer contains small neurons such as stellate cells and basket cells Purkinje layer contains a single layer of flask-shaped Purkinje cells with branching dendrites. questions.text: Name the cartilage shown in the image below .
questions.solution:
Elastic cartilage, also known as yellow fibrocartilage, is similar in many ways to hyaline cartilage. It contains a semi-rigid mesh of collagen fibres in its extracellular matrix and provides structure and flexibility to tissue. However, the collagen fibres in elastic cartilage are interwoven with numerous elastic fibres, forming a network. This elastic matrix gives elastic cartilage the capacity to bear tension and return to its original shape after being stretched or compressed. The elastic fibres are not visible in regular hematoxylin and eosin-stained sections, and require special staining techniques such as resorcin, fusion and orcein to make them visible.

Examples of elastic cartilage: - pinna, epiglottis.


Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 88

questions.text: Which cells are impacted in newborns with respiratory distress syndrome
questions.solution:
Type 2 pneumocytes are affected. Respiratory distress syndrome is seen commonly in pre - term neonates and babies born to diabetic mothers. There is decreased production/lack of surfactant production by Type 2 pneumocytes present in alveoli of lung. As a result there is collapse of alveoli resulting in respiratory distress (tachypnea, chest retractions, grunting and cyanosis). In the given image, A- capillary, B- Type I pneumocye, C- Type II pneumocye and D- lamellar body

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered to have reticular fibers as its structural support system?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Thymus
 
  • Reticular fibers are a type of collagen fiber that form a network of supporting tissue in many organs and tissues.
  • They are found in the spleen, lymph nodes, and bone marrow, where they provide structural support for the cells and tissues of these organs. However, they are not found in the thymus.
  • The thymus is a small, bilobed organ that is located in the upper chest.
  • It is responsible for the production of T cells, which are a type of white blood cell that plays a role in the immune system.
  •  The structural support of the thymus is provided by a network of epithelial cells and fibroblasts.
   



Reference: https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/medicine-and-dentistry/reticular-fiber

The parotid gland has striated and intercalated intralobular ducts, whereas the pancreas has ONLY the intercalated type.

questions.text: Eukaryotes' intercellular communication is mediated by:
questions.solution:
Intercellular communication in eukaryotes is mediated by exosome.

Exosomes are secreted by all types of cells and are also found abundantly in the body fluids such as: saliva, blood, urine and breast milk. The major role of exosomes is to carry the information by delivering various effectors or signalling molecules between specific cells covering a very long distance.


Reference:https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3738855/

questions.text: Which statement is false about the intestinal epithelium:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3:  Good vascular supply
 
  • Epithelial tissue is indeed avascular, meaning it lacks its own blood supply.
  • The constant shedding and replacement of epithelial cells do not require a direct blood supply to sustain them.
  • Instead, nutrients and oxygen diffuse from the underlying connective tissue to nourish the epithelial cells.

Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1181-1184

questions.text: Which is the strongest layer of oesophegus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Submucosa 
 
  • The submucosa is the strongest layer of the esophagus.
  • It is made up of a thick layer of connective tissue that contains elastic fibers, blood vessels, and nerves. The submucosa helps to keep the esophagus open and it also helps to protect the esophagus from injury.
  • The muscularis externa is the layer of smooth muscle that propels food down the esophagus through peristalsis. The adventitia is the outermost layer of the esophagus, consisting of loose connective tissue that anchors the esophagus to surrounding structures. 



Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 1167-1171

questions.text: What is the pecten of the anal canal lined with ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Non keratinized stratified squamous epithelium 
 
  • The pecten (pectinate line) is a junctional area in the anal canal that separates two different types of epithelium.
  • The upper part of the anal canal, above the pecten line, is lined with simple columnar epithelium, which is continuous with the mucosal lining of the rectum.
  • The lower part of the anal canal, below the pecten line, is lined with non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium, which is continuous with the skin of the perianal region.

Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 32

questions.text: What is the name of the additional layer of skin seen in the epidermis of the palms and soles?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Stratum Lucidum
 
  • The additional layer of skin seen in the epidermis of the palms and soles is called Stratum Lucidum.
  • Stratum Lucidum is a translucent layer present in areas of thick skin, such as the palms and soles.
  • This layer is responsible for the clear appearance of thick skin and increases its resistance to friction and abrasion.





Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 145,146,147

questions.text: Which of the following is not related to sebaceous glands?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Glands of Moll
 
  • Sebaceous glands are small, oil-producing glands found throughout the skin, except on the palms and soles.
  • They secrete sebum, an oily substance that helps lubricate and waterproof the skin and hair.
  • Glands of Moll are modified apocrine sweat glands that are found on the margin of the eyelid. They are not related to sebaceous glands.





Reference: Gray’s Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice Edition 42 nd Page no 784,785

questions.text: Which of the marked structure is a merocrine gland?
questions.solution:
• In the given skin histology image - 'D' points toward Sweat glands which are Merocrine in nature
  • B points towards sebaceous glands which are holocrine in nature. 
Merocrine glands
Exocrine glands and their secretions are categorized as merocrine and a cell is considered merocrine if its secretions are ejected onto a body surface or into the lumen via exocytosis from secretory cells into a duct or ducts with an epithelial wall.

Holocrine glands
Holocrine glands are a type of exocrine glands that release their secretions by the rupture and disintegration of entire cells. Eg Sebaceous Glands, Meibomian Glands

questions.text: Identify the histological image below.
questions.solution:
The image above depicts transitional epithelium.

In this tissue, the deepest layer consists of columnar cells, the middle layers comprise polyhedral cells, and the surface layer features large, umbrella-shaped cells.

Transitional epithelium is located in the renal pelvis and calyces, the ureter, the urinary bladder, and part of the urethra. Due to its distribution, it is often referred to as urothelium. Notably, in the urinary bladder, transitional epithelium can stretch significantly without sustaining damage. When stretched, it appears thinner, and the cells become flattened or rounded.

questions.text: Name the hormone produced from zone A and zone C in the given histological cross-section of the adrenal gland.
questions.solution:
Layers of adrenal gland are as follows • Outer zona glomerulosa - small, compact cells. Secretes mineralocorticoids
• Central zona fasciculata - larger lipid-rich cells arranged in radial
columns. Secretes corticosteroids
• Inner zona reticularis - pigmented, compact cells. Secretes androgens.
• Adrenal medulla - thin layer of large chromaffin cells. Secretes catecholamines such as epinephrine and norepinephrine.



Ref- Ganong review of Medical Physiology 26th edition Page 330-331

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in the given histopathology slide.
questions.solution:
The slide displays a portion of the duodenum along with the Brunner's glands, which are marked structures on the duodenum.

Compound tubular submucosal glands called "brunner's glands" or "duodenal glands" are located in the upper duodenum, above the sphincter of Oddi.

The columnar cells that secrete mucus line the alveoli of the duodenal glands. Their ducts exit into the intestinal crypts (of Lieberkuhn) after passing through the muscularis mucosae.

These submucosal glands make it simple to distinguish the duodenum from the jejunum or ileum. There are no glands in the submucosa of the ileum or jejunum.

other options
1. Interstitial cells of Cajal: pacemaker cells of gut, regulate gut motility
2. Crypts of Lieberkuhn: ducts of brunners glands exit into these crypts

Reference
Inderbir Singh's Textbook of Human Histology 8th Edition, Chapter 15, Pg 187

questions.text: The fallopian tube is lined by ____
questions.solution:
The epithelium lining the fallopian tube is a simple layer of ciliated columnar epithelium.
It consists of two main cell types

  1. Ciliated Cells

    • These have hair-like cilia that help move the ovum from the ovary toward the uterus.
    • Cilia beat in a coordinated manner, aided by estrogen, which increases their activity around ovulation.

  2. Secretory (Peg) Cells

    • These are non-ciliated cells that secrete nutrients and protective factors for the ovum and sperm.
    • Their secretions help maintain a favorable environment for fertilization and early embryonic development.

The epithelium varies along the tube:

  • Fimbriae & Infundibulum: Rich in ciliated cells to help capture the ovum.
  • Ampulla: Has the highest number of ciliated cells; this is the main site of fertilization.
  • Isthmus & Interstitial (Intramural) part: Fewer ciliated cells, more peg cells to nourish the embryo before it reaches the uterus.


Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice 41st edition page no 1302

questions.text: Given below is a histological section of the thyroid gland. Which of the following is secreted by the cell marked 'X' in the image?
questions.solution:
The structures marked with an X correspond to the C cells or parafollicular cells of the thyroid gland, which secrete calcitonin.

C cells (clear cells or parafollicular cells) have pale cytoplasm and are found between the follicular cells and the basement membrane or between the follicles. They are usually found in the central third of each lateral lobe of the thyroid gland and are interspersed among thyroid follicles.They are members of the APUD system of diffuse neuroendocrine cells. The thyroid gland secretes calcitonin, which lowers blood calcium levels.

The thyroid gland is surrounded by a fibrous capsule and is divided into lobules by septa. These lobules contain follicles lined with follicular cells, the shape of which depends on the activity of the gland. They are flat when inactive, cubic or columnar when active. The follicular cavity contains a colloid that appears pink on H and E stains.

Reference: Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice 41st edition page no 471
